Faculty Name
Malvika Maheshwari [malvika.maheshwari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

With the rise of Nazism, Stalinism, and monopoly capitalism during the interwar period in Europe, a group of intellectuals came together to examine and diagnose some of challenges that came with this modernity — rise of bureaucracy, mass politics, capitalism, culture industry and the increasing obsession with astrology. While this group of scholars were influenced by Hegel, Marx, Weber, Freud, among others, their analysis moved beyond traditional approaches in political and social theory.

Focusing on the transformative and revolutionary potential of theory, the writings of Max Horkheimer, Walter Benjamin, Theodor Adorno, Herbert Marcuse, Jurgen Habermas—as critical theory—has influenced disciplines as varied as political science, sociology, gender studies, film and cultural studies, comparative literature among others.

Apart from reading the texts written by this first generation of Frankfurt School intellectuals, in the course we will simultaneously study the responses to the development of their thought, particularly their migration to the United States, and their impact on the New Left.

Philosophy of Science [PHI-2240/ PSY-3162] [PHI-2240/ PSY-3162-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Iain Siantonas [alexander.siantonas@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Much human effort is expended on the enterprise we call ‘science’, on the assumption that it allows us to understand, and perhaps manipulate, the world. But what, if anything, might justify this assumption? What’s so special about this enterprise anyway? Such are the questions we explore in the philosophy of science. This course will begin with some of the intellectual roots of what we now call science, in thinkers such as Aristotle and Francis Bacon (not the artist, though we may also mention Roger Bacon). Then we will review the ideas of four crucial 20th century figures: Karl Popper, Thomas Kuhn, Paul Feyerabend, and Imre Lakatos. Finally, we will explore a range of an assortment of topics such as whether electrons are real, whether the failure of past theories gives us reason to doubt the best theories of today, and what the relationship between knowledge and science might be.

Overview

 

Course description:

This course throws a light on the principles of science and central role of chemistry in science. Historically, chemistry has been focusing on the variation of matter, their properties and how these matters can undergo interesting chemical transformations. The intriguing chemical and physical properties of these matters attract the attention of scientific community. Chemistry has been the building block of matters, small to large. Materials at different length scales will be addressed and how different pedagogies can explain matter at varying length scales

Therefore, in this course, we will discuss about principles of science involved in the deeper understanding of matters (from quantum dots to supramolecular arrangements) at different length scales.

Focus will be on concepts and units of lengths, change of paradigm and pedagogy as small molecules become larger molecules, polymers, biomolecules, transition from quantum mechanics to classical mechanics at a pedagogical level. General principles of thermodynamics and kinetics will be highlighted as basic principles of science.

At a chemical length scale, periodic table of elements, their electronic structure and properties, introduction to organic chemistry as a great utility in science from building blocks of life to renewable energy, healthcare, medicines, and materials with value-addition in society will be discussed to understand logic of chemical reactivity.

Learning Outcome: Principles of Science as related to the fundamentals of chemistry and use of these in day-to-day life

Faculty Name
Mayank Garg [mayank.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ,Anurag Agrawal [anurag.agrawal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The principles of science manifest themselves in different ways in different domains of science, but a few things remain constant, namely the scientific method. In the scientific method, we look for internal and external inconsistencies in our models, ensuring that our beliefs are coherent within themselves (internal) and with available data (external). Health is an extremely important subject, relevant to each one of us individually and as a society, but is far more subjective than say physics or maths, where we can speak of fundamental laws of the universe that exist independent of us. Principles of health science teach us about the scientific method, but also about ourselves as a species and society, going beyond the natural sciences. Even used in the restricted context of human health, the meaning changes from birth to death, from past to present, and even from culture to culture. This course provides a view of sccientific thinking in health from multiple lenses, including physiology, digital technology, medical history, and sociology. I hope that this will serve as a model of how to scientifically analyze ‘wicked’ interdisciplinary topics where neither the questions, nor the answers, are well-defined. We will cover the following topics in the context of health:

a) The four paradigms of science: theoretical, experimental, computational simulation driven by theory and experiment, and  lastly discovery from big observational data.  For example, at different stages of human history, how would we differently think about risk of tuberculosis.

b) The disruptive effect of technologies. For example, how did germ theory and microscopes change the field of infectious diseases and public health

c) How to ask a good scientific question. For example, what are the many questions inside "How do we eradicate tuberculosis"?

d) Last, but not least, we will talk about how to go about finding an answer for a well stated question. 

A sub-theme in this course will be the future of health in a digital age, where the fourth paradigm is starting to become operational, disruptive technologies like GenAI are present, but we need to do better in terms of asking the right questions and working across disciplines to answer them. 

Learning Outcomes

Learning how to think scientifically and ask questions, and in the process learn the value of scientific thinking about health, towards better health

Literature and the World [FC-0701] [FC-0701-1]

Faculty Name
Amrita Narayanan [amrita.narayanan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We all narrate ourselves to ourselves, it’s a process that helps us make our way about the world coherently. Yet, our own biography, realistically put, is confining. We can only tell stories about ourselves using the tropes of stories we have heard, and within the limits of our available language. Reading literature allows us access to wide-ranging lives and selves beyond our own self-narrative. Literature also opens up the possibilities of language to describe the experience of the self as it encounters the world. Our course will consider how fictional works from around the world and across time mirror real world complexities: growing-up, falling in love, being happy, having sex, being faithful, losing a friend, losing a way of life and facing death. We will learn to think about books as dreams, understanding how stories change via the shifting question “Whose dream is it?”.  Over the semester we will entertain the idea that fictional characters and books mirror crucial real world-viewpoints, that books mirror each other, and that if a literary work can mirror the reality of living in the world, then perhaps our lives are more fictional than we think.

Learning Outcomes

1. Students will learn how to understand the arguement that is being made by a book or character

2. Students will learn how to re-tell a story from the perspective of another character by shifting the question "Who's dream is it"

3. Student will understand and be able to articulate what constitutes "evidence" in a literary paper.

4. Students will be able to articulate how literature deepens the reader's understanding of psychological themes.

Overview

“Difficult Loves”

This course seeks to reflect on care and love both conceptually and experientially. What does it mean to love and care for oneself and for others? What allows us to love and care? What prevents us from caring and loving ourselves and others? What forces—personal, interpersonal, or collective and communal—regulate, prescribe and even prohibit experiences and expressions of love. As the narrator in Arundhati Roy’s The God of Small Things poignantly reflects, such questions are older than any conception we might have of “history,” and comprise at times unspoken and often unwritten “Love Laws” that determine who can be loved, how and how much.

Our primary goal in the course is to work towards developing a critical and comprehensive language around understanding care and love as the basis for any and all configurations of relationalities that both make and unmake our senses of being in the world. Beginning our journey with selections from The Symposium by Plato, verses from the Gatha Sattasai, and poetry from the Akam repertoire of Sangam literature, we will make our way through more contemporary iterations and meditations on caring and loving such as, Roland Barthes’ A Lover’s Discourse and Ocean Vuong’s On Earth We Are Briefly Gorgeous. All along the way we will be reflecting on and attempting to problematize “traditional” and “normative” structures within which care and love are usually understood and experienced.

Overview

Great Books: Satirical Animals

From the birds of Aristophanes’ Cloudcuckooland to Perumal Murugan’s goat Poonachi, animals have served as a vehicle for satire across cultures and time periods, often as mirrors reflecting societal absurdities, moral failings, human grotesqueness, and political struggles. In this Great Books course, we will get acquainted with some of these satirical animals. We will encounter them as symbols, moral agents, political figures, and detached narrators. This course will, in keeping with the ethos of Foundations courses, familiarize students with methods from the different disciplines of philosophy, history, and literature: we will learn to read closely and critically, identify and respond to arguments, appropriately situate a work in its socio-historical context, and compare texts and ideas from different moments in time and space. By investigating how animals have been portrayed in fables, allegories, and novels, you will gain a deeper understanding of the power of satire in challenging conventions and provoking thought on human nature and society. And, hopefully, it goes without saying, we will also laugh — sometimes until we’re in tears.

Overview

This course guides students through a multiplicity of performance practices existing on the subcontinent. These practices include the locally specific, the socially specific, the traditional, the hereditary, the rural, the nomadic, the urban, the pan-Indian, as well as those practices with discernible connections to performance conventions beyond the specifically Indian context. An important premise of this course is that music, dance and theatre are three strands of an intertwined whole. Their closely related cultural, social and aesthetic histories will constitute the core material to be studied. While acknowledging a cultural corpus often possessing obvious mutual affinities, this course will give pride of place to the wide varieties of performance practices found in India and the divergent histories accompanying them.  Though mainly academic, the course can contain performance elements depending on the students’ inclinations and their performative relationship to the material being studied.

Faculty Name
Vivek Venkitaraman Narayan [v.v.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Is everyday life a performance? Are our social interactions forms of playacting? How about the ways in which we present ourselves—as gendered bodies, as students, as friends, as professors, and as so many other less nameable identities—are these too performances? What would it tell us if we were to think of everyday social interaction and self-presentation as performance? Does this mean our interactions are shallow, our relationships fake, and our personalities mere pretense? Or will it reveal aspects of everyday life that otherwise remain hidden in plain view?   

These are some questions that inspire this course to explore the social phenomenon of performance and its theoretical value to the humanities. We will investigate the ways in which our everyday behaviours and the stories we tell shape our identities and our experience of the world. We will see how thinking of, with, and through performance can help us investigate social behaviour, individual and collective identity, and embodied knowledge. 

We will do so by focusing on three recurring themes: first, the relationship between representation and performance, which will help us understand social behaviour; second, the paradigm of performativity, which is significant to theorizing identity; and third, the debate between whether performance is an ephemeral or enduring phenomenon, which is central to conceptualizing embodied knowledges. We will see, in short, how performance—as object, method, and analytic—can help us understand societies and cultures by focusing on acts of doing, ways of being, and modes of knowing. We will read Judith Butler, JL Austin, Diana Taylor, Richard Schechner, Susan Sontag, Harry Elam, Victor Turner, Bishnupriya Dutt, Erving Goffman, Clifford Geertz, Aparna Dharwadker, Ngugi wa Thiong’o, and Paulla Ebron. We will also engage with Dharamvir Bharati’s Andha Yug, Maya Rao’s Walk, and the real-life cases of Rachel Dolezal and Jessica Krug.

Overview

This course seeks to examine the autobiography or memoir as a literary genre, an historical archive, and an individual/community narrative.

We will also consider how graphic novels, poems and blogs can be seen as constructions of a specific kind of persona.

As the definition of autobiography has expanded over time, different kinds of memoirs and autobiographies have liberated Identity as a singular noun to self-consciously manage our plural or even desired identities and playfully experiment with different notions of selfhood.

 

In this course, we will examine the idea of “truth telling” that is often associated with autobiographies. We also consider how the study of international autobiographies allows us a view of the local in the context of the global.

Learn about the genre of autobiography.

See the historical development and change in the form and content of  autobiography.

Explore the diverse cultural contexts in which autobiographies are produced.

Overview

A rough set of topics is provided in the syllabus, but we can explore really any other system that people are interested in. Every week, one class will involve teaching, and the other will involve discussion and presentations. Overview

CHM 1501- Topics in Chemistry     Spring 2025

Vidya Avasare and Sourav Pal

Chemistry is about study of interacting electrons and how the details form a variety of matter that is useful to the society, from renewable energy to healthcare. Historically, chemistry has been focusing on the variation of matter, how transformation takes place and that variation is reflected in a great variety of subjects. The topics in chemistry will cover the role of electrons, as manifested from quantum principles and how the interaction of electrons play crucial role in transformation of substances. The course will involve references and literature reading/ presentation by students, in addition to the standard teaching practices, on the topics to be covered. Cell Biology and Genetics Lab [BIO-2202] [BIO-2202-1]

Faculty Name
Krishna Venkata Melnattur [krishna.melnattur@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sandeep Ameta [sandeep.ameta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course aims to teach students the basic concepts of Cell Biology and Genetics.  In the first module (by Sandeep Ameta), students will be taught the concepts and experiments for Forward Genetics by subjecting microorganisms to harsh environmental conditions and observing the phenotypes. The second module complements the first module by focusing on reverse genetics using the classic eukaryotic model system – Drosophila. The course will provide students with a basic understanding and hands-on experience in handling, manipulating, and investigating cell-biology problems using genetic tools. Importantly, this is a discovery-based course, students will not simply replicate known results, but instead actively participate in generating new knowledge. The goal is to stimulate students’ interest in life sciences through inquiry-based learning. In the process, students will also advance their understanding of the field more broadly.

Learning Outcomes

During this course, the students will learn:

  • Handling/ culturing/ growth of Pseudomonas or E. coli.
  • Forward genetics screen / Random mutagenesis and isolation of conditional mutants in Pseudomonas or E. coli.
  • Exposure/ handling of Drosophila as a model organism 
  • Understanding basic genetics – dominant vs recessive markers, autosomal vs sex linked inheritance.
  • Use of balancer chromosomes, design of crossing schemes,  crossing flies
  • Use of bipartite expression systems (e.g. GAL4/ UAS) to manipulate genes, reverse genetics using RNAi
  • Qualitative and quantitative analysis of behaviour including appropriate graphic visualisation, and statistics
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Knowledge of basic cell biology, microbiology and bacterial genetics will help. Examples of some good textbooks: ‘Genetics’ by Russell, ‘Genes’ by Levin et al, ‘Molecular Genetics’ by Stent

Media as Peacebuilding in South Asia [MS-2342/ IR-2034] [MS-2342/ IR-2034-1]

Faculty Name
Maya Mirchandani [maya.mirchandani@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

A deep dive into how diplomatic correspondents decode foreign policy through different lenses/frameworks of media studies.  

This course focuses on the role of the media in diplomacy and foreign policy in South Asia especially with regard to reporting on contentious issues. Limiting the geography to SAARC countries, the aim is to research and analyze the manner in which different forms of the media act as both a part of the policy message, as well as represent civil society concerns in a post-colonial, post partition subcontinent. 

The course will also introduce students to an overview of how the Indian media has historically helped construct the idea of South Asia, and help to understand why, and how certain stories come to dominate.

The course will include guest lectures from diplomatic correspondents across the South Asian region mainly from members of the South Asian Women in Media collective of women journalists in the SAARC countries. 

Learning Outcomes

Through lectures, guest speakers, and class discussions, presentations and assignments, students will learn how to navigate foreign ministry websites, distinguish different forms of diplomatic communication, and understand the craft of reporting on diplomacy which involves writing skills, nuance and objectivity. It will also introduce students to how mass media is leveraged through storytelling formats to dominate narratives. 

Students will also learn the history of the oldest newspapers of the subcontinent, learn about media trends in individual countries and become aware of the different forms of media consumption that aim to build bridges through music, cinema and cultural exchanges in the real and virtual worlds. Some case studies will be used through the semester, including Coke Studio, Himal Magazine , South Asian Women in Media, etc.

Overview

This course is about ideas that illuminate the economic organization of our society.  Real world examples will be used to discuss the power and limits of these ideas.  To do this we have to ask questions of things that one takes for granted.

What does it mean to say there is no `free lunch’? And why does it matter? What are the predictable consequences of incentives Vs command and control? What do those terms even mean? Why is the rupee note not a worthless piece of paper? Why does it have value? Does trust matter to economic life and GDP? Why do we not pay for Gmail? Why is it so easy to access high-tech gadgets (if you have the money) but not so easy to enjoy clean water and air (even if you have the money)? Should the government ban polluting industries? What’s the alternative? Why is construction labour toiling in the sun paid much less than white collar work done drinking coffee?  What does Taylor Swift’s sell out concerts say about livelihoods in a digital economy.  How does it matter to inequality?

Learning Outcomes

The main objective of this course is to persuade the student to question things that they took for granted.

A second objective is to introduce a limited set of ideas that are powerful in explaining the organization of economic life.

Overview

This course explores the dynamic interplay between the economic system, social institutions, and political landscape. Students will develop critical thinking skills to understand and analyze the interdependence and interpret the present realities of the capitalist society in which we live and imagine its past and future. The course also introduces students to the features (e.g. consumerism, alienation, inequality) of capitalist society in contemporary times. We attempt to understand the manifestation of these features in connection with our lives like its impact on culture, aspirations, work environment, and health in society. The course also enables the students to understand the role played by the state in today’s globalized world and evaluate political processes and institutions. The course concludes by examining the currents of technological change, the internet, and media to imagine our future in capitalist societies. So broadly we cover these four themes; a) The Historical Evolution of Capitalism b) Capitalism and Globalisation, c) Features of Capitalist societies, and d) Technology, Mass Media, and the Future of Capitalist societies.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

1. Understand the interwoven relationship across the contemporary world's political, social, and economic spectrum.

2. Critically evaluate the competing arguments for the “Why” of our social, political, and economic realities and articulate their arguments.

3. Develop an eye for interdisciplinarity while analyzing social realities and changes.

Calculus [MAT-1000] [MAT-1000-1]

Faculty Name
Sarvesh Ravichandran Iyer [sarvesh.iyer@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Our aim is to start by defining the real numbers, on which calculus will be
performed. So first, we will lead up to the real numbers naturally,while seeing
the integers and rational numbers along the way.
Having reached the real numbers, we will then explore how calculus helps
us understand the notion of infinity. This will be done by defining sequences
and series, which provide a standard mechanism to deal with infinitely many
quantities.
We will then move to functions on real numbers, which are the fundamental
objects on which calculus is performed. We will try to understand functions
from a graphical point of view as well, by seeing how to draw/sketch graphs of
functions.
Then, we come to the notion of limits and continuous functions, which are
very natural examples of functions that can be studied under the umbrella of
calculus.
Then, we come to one of the fundamental operations of calculus : the dif-
ferentiation operation. We define differentiable functions, and then look at the
advantage of how differentiation helps constrain functions : this would include
e.g. the mean value theorem and the famous L’Hopital’s rule for limits of ratios
of functions.
Then, we look at generalizations of the mean value theorem, which are the
Taylor and Maclaurin series.
Having studied differentiation in detail, we now move to integration, defining
carefully the theory of Riemann integration. We then study various definite and
indefinite integrals, understanding along the way techniques to solve them.
Finally, the fundamental theorem of calculus completes the discussion. The
rest of the course focuses on the applications of calculus : this includes optimiza-
tion by setting the derivative to zero, and applications of calculus to mechanics.
As references, we will use


1. J. Stewart: Calculus, Cengage Publishers, 2012.

2. K. A. Ross: Elementary Analysis, The Theory of Calculus, Second Edi-
tion, Undergraduate Texts in Mathematics, Springer, 2013.

3. G. B. Thomas and R. L. Finney: Calculus and Analytic Geometry, Second
Edition, Addison-Wesley Publishing, 1998.

Overview

This is an elective course in advanced macroeconomics. This course will study macroeconomic policy by understanding crucial components of the macroeconomy – monetary policy and fiscal policy. In the first half of the course, we will look at consumption, investment, and risk-sharing in basic life cycle models, budget deficit, government debt dynamics, and fiscal policy. We will then focus on banks, their role in the monetary system, and how they interact with the central monetary institutions. We will develop a deeper understanding of the monetary transmission mechanism and how banks impact inflation beyond the central bank's control.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course students should have a firm understanding of:

• Consumption and Investment Models

• Macroeconomic Models of Fiscal Policy and Government Debt Dynamics

• Monetary Policy Making with and without Financial Frictions

• Policy Making to Promote Growth

Faculty Name

Overview

Why are some countries so poor and others so rich? Can governments act to eliminate poverty? What sorts of interventions work? How do we evaluate them? Through this course, you will question the meaning of economic development and identify the factors that affect growth, poverty and inequality. You will engage with contemporary research on markets, institutions, education, agriculture, and caste. You will analyse these questions by using both theoretical frameworks as well as empirical evidence. In doing so, you will gain an insight into the challenges and constraints faced by developing countries in their quest to improve the quality of human life

Learning Outcomes

On successful completion of this course, you would have learnt

some of the ways economists have tried to model economic growth, and how one can relate the model to the data

the factors that shape long run differences in growth across countries

how the developing country context affects markets for land, credit, and insurance

how economists have tried to evaluate interventions in a key area of market failure – education

how economists have begin to study questions of group identity – particularly caste, discrimination and affirmative action

some methods in the toolkit of causal inference, notably randomized controlled experiments, natural experiments, as well as quasi-experimental setups such as instrumental variables, difference-in-differences, and regression discontinuity designs.

courseTitle: Conservation Policy in the Developing World
description:
Conservation Policy in the Developing World [ES-2002/ POL-2069/ SOA-2226] [ES-2002/ POL-2069/ SOA-2226-1]

Faculty Name
Ghazala Shahabuddin [ghazala.shahabuddin@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course delves into the policies relating to biodiversity conservation in developing countries with reference to its ecological, historical and socio-political contexts.  The primary intent of this course is to enable students to integrate biodiversity concerns with sustainable development and socio-economic imperatives. The course will begin with giving an understanding of the ecological processes underlying extinction and ecosystem degradation as well as its consequences for society. The historical and political dimensions of species loss/extinction will also be discussed. The course will then turn to critically exploring past and prevalent paradigms and strategies for biodiversity conservation such as strict nature protection, Integrated Conservation and Development (ICDP), community-based conservation, crop certification, Payment for Ecosystem Services (PES) and ecotourism,  with the aid of key international case studies. In addition, current debates on Indian wildlife laws and policies will be discussed using case studies. The aim of this course is to use perspectives from a variety of disciplines, including ecology, history, political science, economics and sociology, to develop a holistic view of today’s biodiversity crisis and its solutions. Students will be taken on a field trip to Mandothi wetlands, Haryana where they will apply their course learning to the issue of wetland conservation in production landscapes.

 

Learning Outcomes

The students will learn to integrate knowledge from different disciplinary areas and sources (scholarly literature, audio-visual resources and traditional knowledge systems) to understand real-life biodiversity conservation in terms of science, policy and on-ground implementation. They will also learn to critically analyze policy documents related to conservation and write well-referenced commentaries on various topics. Students will learn how to engage in productive class debates based on the readings and documentaries that they are assigned.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

 

List of Topics/Modules

Modules 1,2,3: Causes of Biodiversity Loss

This module will discuss the causes of biodiversity loss, specifically, habitat loss, land-use change, habitat fragmentation, invasives, climate change, pollution and overkill (hunting). Students will discuss varying perspectives on the primary causes of biodiversity loss, through juxtaposing arguments from Gold (2003), Tal (2018) and Barnard and Emmanuel (2014).

Module 4,5,6: Strictly Protected Areas: History and Management

The concept of strictly protected areas (SPA) is discussed. SPAs are an important manifestation of the exclusionary mode of conservation as practised globally. Due to the way they are designed and implemented, they have led to widespread alienation of local residents due to displacement, curtailment of access to natural resources and human-wildlife conflict. At the same time, they have proven useful in being able to save species from extinction. However, poor application of science, financial shortages, poor governance and administration, and lack of specific management objectives have led to a situation where in many cases ecosystem degradation is as high inside PAs as outside. In this module we explore the history, management and effectiveness of PAs with an emphasis on the importance of ecosystem management for preserving biodiversity.

Module 7,8: Exploring Policies on Conservation-Induced Displacement

Displacement of local residents has been a way to create inviolate spaces for protected areas across the world, with implications for environmental justice. In this module, we explore the specific policies for conservation-induced displacement from Tiger Reserves in India, with reference to the law and the implementation processes.

Module 9,10: Human-Wildlife Conflicts

This module explores the many dimensions of human-wildlife conflict- that is responsible for considerable damage to human lives and livelihoods in developing countries. Wild animals damage crops, kill livestock and injure and kill humans, many of whom already belong to marginalised sections of society. The behavioural, historical, ecological and political factors that determine extent and intensity of conflict are discussed, as well as the consequences for human-animal relations. Mitigative strategies including insurance and compensatory schemes, creation of corridors and village relocation are also discussed through a case study on elephant-human conflict.

Module 11,12: Institutions and Institutional Weakness

Forest institutions are key to effective long-term conservation, yet there is little understanding of their structure and functioning in developing countries. In India, forest institutions bear the historical burden of exclusionary management established by the colonial administration, whose legacy influences us to the present day. Students will read a set of key papers examining this aspect of wildlife conservation. They will also watch the movie Sherni (2021) to delve deeply into the issues facing forest institutions in India and elsewhere.

Module  13,14

The Integrated Conservation & Development (ICDP) Model

The Integrated Conservation & Development (ICDP) Model came about as a reaction to the dominant exclusionary mode of conservation practices in most developing countries. It aims to reduce the adverse impact of PA on people’s livelihoods while at the same time, reducing the anthropogenic impact on nature.  To what extent can this win-win situation be realised? Is ICDP basically an inherently flawed model or are there conditions and circumstances under which ICDP can be successful in a developing economy? These are some of the questions being explored in this module.

Module 16: Field Trip

Students will be taken on a field trip to Mandothi village and wetlands, Jhajjar District, Haryana. Students will apply their learnings from the course to explore the modalities and complexities of wildlife conservation in the larger landscape comprising human settlements and agriculture. There will be a guided class discussion based on the field trip and the assigned readings.

Module 17,18: Community-Based Conservation

The view that wild areas largely managed by indigenous communities and local residents, lately named community conserved areas or CCAs, can be effective in saving species and ecosystems from extinction, is rapidly gaining ground. Yet several scholars have pointed out that local management can result in unsustainable use which detracts from conservation. Varying perspectives on the usefulness and effectiveness of CCAs on different continents will be discussed in this module.

Module 19,20: Conservation outside Protected Areas: Cities, Fields and Fallows

In this module, we discuss the possibilities of biological conservation in landscapes devoted to production, particularly, agriculture. Trade-offs between biodiversity conservation and agricultural production have become increasingly visible. Traditional means of agriculture that focus on subsistence actually encourage biodiversity over large scales; increasing intensification can lead to local elimination of a range of species. In a world where food production is being prioritized, it is necessary to understand these trade-offs and the production systems that may allow for coexistence with wild species. In this context, global ‘land-sharing’ as opposed to ‘land-sparing’ strategies will be discussed. Students will be introduced to urban ecology which is another important area of conservation, given the large-scale transition from rural to urban settlement during the last few decades.

Modules 21,22: Economic Incentives for Conservation

Several ways to induce conservation-oriented behaviour based on financial benefits have been experimented with during the last few decades such as debt-for-nature swaps, direct payments, payments for environmental services, timber certification and conservation easements. Payment for Environmental Services (PES) has recently emerged as an important financial tool for encouraging biodiversity conservation. In these modules, PES is examined from the ecological, political and historical perspectives and evaluated as a conservation tool in developing countries, using Costa Rica as a case study. We will also discuss the effectiveness, constraints and potential of ecotourism as a conservation tool, based on examples from South America and India.

Module 23: Invasives and human well-being

(Guest Lecture by Dr. Ankila Hiremath, ATREE)

Module 24: Ecosystem Restoration: Ecology and Politics

Students will be exposed to two restoration examples- one of a grassland in Maharashtra, and one of a scrub forest in Haryana through video recordings. These examples will demonstrate the social-ecological complexities of ecosystem restoration. Based on these examples, they will debate viable means of restoration.

Module 25,26: Case Study on Wetland conservation

Wetlands are one of the most widespread and biodiverse ecosystems worldwide, ranging from rivers that can be seen as the fount of civilization, and human-made lakes created for everyday use.  Yet they are poorly understood in terms of ecology and human use, and subject to misuse, pollution and misgovernance. Further, rural and urban communities who are dependent on these ecosystems have been as marginalised as the ecosystems themselves largely due to the process of urbanization. In this module, the complex social ecology of wetlands will be explored. In this session, we will revisit many of the issues emerging out of the earlier field trip to Mandothi wetland. Students, through break-out sessions, will be asked to debate the policy changes that are required for long-term conservation of wetlands that can imbibe both social and ecological values, based on the field trip, a documentary and course readings.

The successful completion of this course will depend upon intensive reading, timely completion of assignments and tests, in-class student presentations and participation in discussions. Students should show in-depth engagement with readings and lectures. 40-50 pages of reading will be assigned each week.   Students will be evaluated on the basis of one essay assignment, a mid-term test and a final term paper in this course. In addition, students will be graded on their attendance, class presentations and participation.

Democratization and Foreign Aid [POL-3074/ IR-3021] [POL-3074/ IR-3021-1]

Faculty Name
Bann Seng Tan [bannseng.tan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The core concern of the course is to analyse the ways foreign aid might or might not work when it comes to democracy promotion. Since this concern links two concept groups, this course doubles as a stylized and brief introduction to the literature on foreign aid and democratization. In democratization (Part I), we will consider the type of foreign interventions, the drivers of democratization, the special role of elections and the varieties of authoritarianism. In Foreign aid (Part II), we will cover the types of foreign aid, the efficacy debate, the modalities of democracy aid, the incentive of aid donors and recipients and donor switching.

 

After the theoretical overview, we consider a practical approach to existing political constraints (Part III), as articulated in my book, Liberalization at the Margins. We skim the empirics and put more emphasis on the case studies of the aid-democratization dynamic for Egypt, Fiji, and Myanmar. We conclude by considering the policy implications of such strategies with an emphasis on the authoritarian backlash (and authoritarian strategies for international law.)

This course is dual listed under both International Relations (IR) and Political Science (PS).

The attached syllabus is a older draft.

Learning Outcomes

Through the course, students should be able to 1) identify the major issues and debates in foreign aid, 2) analyse the costs and benefits of various modalities of democracy aid, and 3) consider the policy implications of democracy promotion. Students also have the opportunity, through the term essay, to specialize on the aid dynamics of a given country and understand why democracy promotion frequently fails. As a bonus, students get a sense of the background work that goes into the writing of a book, They may appreciate (or not!) that what you see the finished product – the book - is merely the tip iceberg. It is the part that is underwater and not immediately obvious where the real labor lies.

This is not a course on current events.

MA Proseminar II: Thesis Writing [ENG-5004] [ENG-5004-1]

Faculty Name
Subhasree Chakravarty [subhasree.chakravarty@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Writing a dissertation, as you will soon realize, is an intimate and personal process. Some even go as far as calling it akin to childbirth, but I will spare you the gendered imagery. Yet, I will say it is indeed intimate, private, personal and momentous. At the same time, graduate students often feel that writing within an academic institution does not bear much relevance to their lives outside of academia. To dispel such myths and make more happy ones for ourselves, in this course we will ask; How should we begin to think about writing? How is it possible to learn to write? Is writing purely a technical craft? What is criticism and how do we write critically about literature?

While we discuss and disagree on the answers to these questions, we will also learn about all the delicate ways in which a hypothesis can be formulated, how to fashionably synthesize materials from written sources, organize ideas in almost perfect forms and develop marvelously captivating arguments.

Transnational Transgender [ENG-4502] [ENG-4502-1]

Faculty Name
Madhavi Menon [menon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Translating the transitions that trans* theory asks us to make, this class will think about trans* theory transnationally. For too long considered the outcome of Western liberalism, trans* theory and narratives in fact exist in several shapes around the world. Whether it is the Sufi mehfil of erotic transcendence, the Indic landscape of hijras, or the Thai ecosystem of lady-boys, trans* theory has a rich life scattered across cultural and sexual geographies. We will transition across some of this terrain over the course of the semester as we are transported by texts from Iran (Afsaneh Najmabadi), India (Serena Nanda, Gayatri Reddy, Bullhe Shah), Taiwan (Qiu Miaojin), and France (Paul Preciado), among others. All along these travels, we will be guided by the etymological sense of "trans" as something that moves beyond what we think we know and how we like to think.

Apparitions of Macbeth [ENG-4203] [ENG-4203-1]

Faculty Name
Jonathan Gil Harris [jgharris@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Macbeth stands unsurpassed among Shakespeare’s works for its capacity to frighten.  It is not just that it features scary Witches who predict the future in riddles, or a murderous tyrant who strikes terror into every corner of his kingdom.  Much of the power of the play derives from its staging of eerie, unsettling apparitions – a floating dagger, a bloody ghost, a series of visions that emerge from a cauldron.  Even the name of the play has acquired a legendary apparitional power: merely to mention it in a playhouse is supposed to conjure unspeakably bad luck.  What is behind the play’s ability to scare the heck out of us?  This seminar will scrutinize Macbeth and its terrifying apparitions.  As we will see, these apparitions are not just plot points or theatrical special effects.  They are also emblematic of the spectral power of matter to conjure untimely possibilities and impossibilities – to make us feel, as Lady Macbeth says, “the future in the instant.”  We will consider how Macbeth’s apparitions have eerily predicted subsequent apparitions of the play, in theory (Sigmund Freud’s account of psychological attachment, Terry Eagleton’s analysis of capitalist reification, Michel Serres’s imagining of human-non-human assemblages) and in cinema (Polanski’s Macbeth, Kurosawa’s Throne of Blood, Bhardwaj’s Maqbool, Jayaraj’s Veeram).  In the process, we will treat the “apparitional” as a theoretical lens that helps us think about the temporalities of political conflicts involving tradition and modernity, indigeneity and cosmopolitanism, globalisation and planetary turmoil, violent tyranny and resistance.

Learning Outcomes

Overview

The purpose of this course is three-fold - learn social theory, see how well (or not) it is applied to international relations, and lastly, create your own social theory.  The central objective of the course is to provoke students to consider how international politics might be understood from the perspectives of various social theories. The readings combine some limited taste of the theorist herself, as well as some applications of that theory in the IR literature. In terms of the workload, the Punjabi proverb rull te gaye aan par chass badi aayi ay (We were ruined in the process, but it sure was fun!) comes to mind. This is going to be a seminar format class, so please make sure you read before coming to class.

The course requirements entail a very close reading of the texts, and animated discussion of them. We read some big thinkers - Berger & Luckmann, Goffman, Marx, Bourdieu, Gramsci, Dubois, Giddens, Ambedkar, and Fanon (among others). The assessment includes weekly presentations of the readings, as well as memos on the readings distributed to class by 6pm the evening before class. A final written paper is required, and oh, did I mention, it is 8000 words (which I think is hardly enough when you have to craft a theory of your own).

Overview

This is a hands-on laboratory course with both indoor and outdoor experiments.  Students are given training to handle an optical telescope and a radio telescope, a theodolite, a sextant and other related equipment.  They measure the temperature of the Sun and several other bright stars, learn how to measure distances using parallax and how to infer the latitude and longitude of a location from the position of stars.  Experiments involving important techniques used regularly in Astrnomy, including astrophotography, photometry, emission and absorption spectroscopy and the study of Doppler effect, are performed.   The experiments include the measurement of the hyperfine spectral transition of hydrogen, the most abundant element, using a homemade radio telescope.

The Violent Universe [PHY-3860/ AST-3860] [PHY-3860/ AST-3860-1]

Faculty Name
Kandaswamy Subramanian [kandaswamy.subramanian@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor: Kandaswamy Subramanian

Violent phenomena like energetic explosions, jet-like ejection of matter or sudden collapse of stars are very common in the Universe.  These phenomena play a key role in controlling the energetics of gas in galaxies and the synthesis and dispersal of heavy elements.   Of late, major emphasis has been placed globally on the study of such events and new information is emerging rapidly.  This course will acquaint the student with the physical processes associated with these violent events and the wealth of information that can be gleaned from them about the evolution of the universe.

Syllabus:

  1. Introduction to violent phenomena - explosions, implosions, ejections, jets - Big Bang, Novae, Supernovae, Gamma Ray Bursts, Solar Flares, Pulsars, Magnetars, Fast Radio Bursts, Accreting compact objects, Active Galactic Nuclei.
  2. Loss of Hydrostatic Equilibrium - Gravitational energy - Explosions and Implosions - Thermodynamic and Thermonuclear instability - Magnetospheric phenomena -  relevant time scales
  3. Collisions of planets, stars, galaxies and clusters; supernova remnants, Gamma Ray Burst afterglows; Radio Galaxies and Quasars
  4. Generation of Electromagnetic radiation, Gravitational Waves and Explosive Nucleosynthesis in violent events.
  5. Cosmological impact of violent events
Learning Outcomes

1 Developing familiarity with energetic cosmic phenomena

2. Understanding the diverse physical processes associated with violent cosmic events

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites (desirable): Physical science at the std XI-XII level, FCs on QRMT and PoS

Recommended reading:

  1. High Energy Astrophysics, M. Longair, Cambridge University Press
  2. Violent Phenomena in the Universe, J.V. Narlikar, Dover
Grading Rubric

1. Assignments (4): 50%

2. Mid-term examination: 20%

3. Final examination: 30%

 

Attendance Policy

Attendance requirement: 80%

Faculty Name
Kandaswamy Subramanian [kandaswamy.subramanian@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor: Kandaswamy Subramanian

Fluid dynamics is at the heart of most  Astrophysical phenomena, and many of these processes have close parallels in Geophysics.  In this course the fluid dynamical principles will be introduced with specific applications to Astrophysical and Geophysical problems.  The topics covered will include hydrostatic equilibrium, accretion flows, shock waves, radiative gas dynamics and magnetohydrodynamics.

Syllabus:

Continuity, Euler and Navier-Stokes equations, Compressible and Incompressible fluids; Potential flows; Effect of rotation - cyclones and climate systems; Gasdynamics in gravitational field - Hydrostatic Equilibrium, Virial Theorem, Accretion flows; Shock Waves, Radiative Hydrodynamics; Induction equation and introduction to MHD - Terrestrial and Astrophysical Dynamos.

Learning Outcomes

The student will learn to appreciate the wide variety of contexts where the physics of fluids play an essential role in governing phenomena in both terrestial contexts and the Univere at large.

Derivatives and Risk Management [FIN-3004] [FIN-3004-1]

Faculty Name
Sidharth Sinha [sidharth.sinha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Futures and Options are the two basic derivative securities.  Derivative securities get their name from the fact that their value and risk is ‘derived’ from the value and risk of the underlying asset.  They enable transfer of risk of the underlying asset without actually transferring the underlying asset.

This course provides the conceptual basis and tools and techniques for pricing derivative securities and using them for risk management of market exposures.

While derivatives are one of the most mathematically sophisticated areas of finance, it is possible to explain the fundamental principles in simple-to-understand and relatively non-mathematical terms.  This course, while being formal and rigorous, also builds the accompanying intuition, essential for effective use of derivative securities.

Learning Outcomes

This course provides the conceptual basis and tools and techniques for pricing derivative securities and using them for risk management of market exposures.

While being formal and rigorous, this course also builds the accompanying intuition, essential for effective use of derivative securities.

Empirical Monetary Policy and Finance [FIN-3031/ ECO-3304] [FIN-3031/ ECO-3304-1]

Faculty Name
Varun Khandelwal [varun.khandelwal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We will examine the role of monetary policy during major macroeconomic events of the last century: the Great Depression, the stagflation of the 1970s and early 1980s, the East Asian crisis, the Dot-Com bust, the Global Financial Crisis, and, most recently, the COVID-19 pandemic. We will correlate the impact of monetary policy with trends in interest rates, foreign exchange rates, and asset prices. Finally, we will apply the lessons learned from these historical events to understanding current macroeconomic conditions.

Learning Outcomes

The primary objective of this course is to encourage students to apply the theoretical concepts learned during the previous two years. The course will emphasize the impact of economic policies on financial asset markets and the broader economy.

By the end of the course, students should have a solid understanding of the causes and consequences of the Great Depression, the shifts in monetary policy since the 1980s, and the factors leading to the subprime housing bubble and the 2008 financial crisis. Students are expected to be able to apply these insights to assess the financial and political implications of major economic events from the past 15 years, including the Eurozone debt crisis, the taper tantrum, demonetization, and the post-COVID monetary policy environment.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course assumes a solid grasp of the macroeconomics concepts covered over the past two years.

Please note that there is no designated textbook. Instead, students will engage in extensive reading across diverse materials, including academic papers, news articles, industry research, and more. These resources will be provided as the course advances. 

Grading Rubric

• 50% – Two individual assignments (25% each)

• 25% – End-of-term group research and presentation

• 20% – Class participation 

• 5% – Attendance 

Group Presentation - the class will be divided into groups of three students. Each group will research a specific question, co-author a paper of 2,500 to 5,000 words, and present their findings to the class. Presentations will be followed by a short Q&A session.

Class Participation - includes three assignments worth 5 marks each, with the top two scores being considered. The remaining 10 points will be based on the quality of contributions to in-class discussions.

Attendance Policy

Since this is an applied course with no specific course text, it is critical that students participate in lectures and discussions therein. After the first four lectures, the loss rate will be 1pc per lecture subject to a maximum of 10pc.

The advanced immunology course builds on foundational knowledge of the immune system, equipping students to analyze, evaluate, and apply immunological concepts to current research. Faculty Name

Overview

The three-dimensional structures of biological macromolecules have helped us to understand the atomic details of biological reactions and their implications. We have exploited the structural information to understand molecular mechanisms of disease biology and help drive drug discovery efforts. While the experimental methods (such as X-ray crystallography, NMR, and cryogenic electron microscopy) remain the methods of choice to understand macromolecular structures, the recent advancements in the field of protein structure prediction tools (such as AlphaFold and RoseTTAFold) have brought about an exciting phase in structural bioinformatics. An advanced methodologies course in structural biology aims to equip students with recent developments in the field of structural biology. In this session, we will be covering topics related to protein structure determination, structure prediction, macromolecular modeling, searching for structural homologs, structural and sequence alignment, and visualizing protein structures to extract maximum information from the structures. The course will mostly be in computational and theoretical study mode. We may also plan a day trip to visit high-end instruments (X-ray diffraction, cryo-EM) available at DST SATHI Central Research Facility IIT Sonipat/Delhi.

Learning Outcomes

The students will learn various methods of macromolecular structural prediction, visualization, search of structural and functional homologs, and analysis. We will be using in silico prediction methods and learning to use them to design our scientific research projects. This program will prepare the students to use structural biology-related methods to utilize them for their scientific pursuits.

Overview

Our day-to-day life highly depends on electronic devices. Hence, studying electronics has become more important than ever. Faculty Name

Overview

This course introduces students to modern Indian literatures in English translation. We will be discussing the works of Rabindranath Tagore, Premchand, Intizar Hussain, Ambai, Kiran Nagarkar, U R Ananthamurthy, Vaikom Muhammad Bashir and Indira Goswami among others. We will also be screening film adaptations of the key works of some of these authors. The course will pay special attention to such movements in Indian literature as the Progressive Writers movement and regional modernisms. We shall be exploring the questions of caste, class, gender and nation in Indian literatures and study different genres such as the novel, short story and poetry. The theorists and critics we will read, in order to situate our discussion of Indian literature in a wider historical, political and theoretical context, include Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak, Walter Benjamin, Gilles Deleuze, Shamsur Rahman Faruqi and G.N.Devy. Is there an “Indian” literature? What is the relation between modern literatures in Indian languages and the forms of the nation? What are the theoretical and political stakes in the debate(s) on realism and modernism in Indian literatures? How do we think the idea of a ‘comparative literature’ in relation to Indian literatures? How do we approach the politics and ethics of translation in the situation opened up by translations from and between Indian languages? These are some of the questions we will address in this course.

Reading Psychoanalytic Writing [ENG-4812] [ENG-4812-1]

Faculty Name
Amrita Narayanan [amrita.narayanan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The radical project known as psychoanalysis began simultaneously as a clinical method and a writing genre.  We could perhaps think of psychoanalytic writing as a form of creative non-fiction, occupying an intermediate terrain between real world observations and the analyst-writer’s imagination and literary taste. Our course includes psychoanalytic writing on a range of themes including: memory, desire, the transference, reading, playing, language and depression. Before the mid-term, we will read from the foundations of psychoanalysis in the four oldest schools: Freudian, Kleinian, British Middle-school and Lacanian.  After the mid-term we will read contemporary psychoanalytic writing on the themes of mourning, violence, colonization and sexual perversity.  As we absorb the language of psychoanalysis and learn to translate back and forth between psychoanalytic and literary registers, we will keep thinking about what makes psychoanalytic writing psychoanalytic.  One of these features, our course argues, is that the status of the relationship between the imaginary and the real is never quite settled:  sometimes on the side of control and other times in support of the wildness of the imagination, psychoanalysis constantly argues with itself about how radical it wants to be.

Grading Rubric

Class Participation (20%) Our course is reading intensive and depends on your classroom engagement. Class attendance is mandatory and class participation forms a substantial part of your grade and contributes to our joint interpretive process. Our format will be a combination of lecture and discussion with lecture time becoming less and discussion time becoming more as we cover more ground and as you acquire sufficient vocabulary to discuss the readings in light of previous readings.

Journals (15%) In addition to public class participation, you are also required to write your thoughts on the reading in a notebook that you keep aside for this purpose.  Each set of readings must be rendered into ten timed minutes of notebook-writing on what the reading has evoked for you personally.  I will read the journals to make sure you have understood the purpose of what you are doing, but will treat the content without judgment.  If you miss a class you must catch up on your journal entry for the reading after, a number of missed entries will result in a low grade. 

Midterm (25%) Immediately after the mid-term break, we will have an in-class handwritten open-book midterm exam.  You will be provided with the mid-term question in the class that precedes it.

Final (40%) Your final consists of a 12-15 page paper that is a piece of self-authored psychoanalytic writing in which you put one theory text in conversation with another, or use two or more theory texts to re-describe and expand a literary work or a real world problem.  You must speak with me about your plan for the final and get my approval on your topic prior to writing.

description:
The Reconstruction of Thought: Muhammad Iqbal and Friedrich Nietzsche [ENG-3331] [ENG-3331-1]

Faculty Name
Huzaifa Omair Siddiqi [huzaifa.siddiqi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Friedrich Nietzsche’s philosophy seems to have had two dominant effects in the theoretical currents that sought to recover his thought from Fascist appropriation in the 20th century: a suspicious and cautious deconstruction of given metaphysical systems or the speculative and playful construction of concepts. The question of what is noble, which is perhaps Nietzsche’s most interesting question, is what is repressed in this project (and as such returns to vitiate its egalitarian claims in various ways). In this course we will see how one of South Asia’s first readers of Nietzsche, the Urdu and Persian poet Muhammad Iqbal, gave a centrality to this problem in both his poetry and his philosophical prose. In this course we will read both Nietzsche’s works as well as Iqbal’s poems (in translation) and prose along with some other thinkers of that period like Henri Bergson and A.N. Whitehead. The objective of this course is to come to an understanding of what Iqbal meant by reconstruction and what that entails for our understanding of a political and philosophical position that takes the question of nobility seriously.

courseTitle: Women, War, and Politics: Gender in Politics and in Violence
description:
Women, War, and Politics: Gender in Politics and in Violence [POL-2088/ IR-2043] [POL-2088/ IR-2043-1]

Faculty Name
Dipin Kaur [dipin.kaur@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course makes a semester-long case for using gender as an effective lens to understand (a) political participation and representation, and (b) contexts affected by political violence. While it is well-established that male bodies make up the vast majority of decision-makers and participants in quotidian electoral politics, the same logic applies to contexts affected by conflict and war. Conventionally, male bodies are considered to be at the forefront of decision-making about whether to go to war, and on the frontlines of said wars as fighters.

In the last few decades, however, these constructions of masculinity and femininity have come to be questioned. Instead, the understanding that gender affects the way in which we see and make sense of the world around us – and that men and women experience and affect wartime and electoral dynamics differently – has come front and center. In the same spirit, we will focus on the role of women in political decision-making and participation; their role both as perpetrators of violence as combatants (and terrorists), as victims and as survivors of male-victimizing atrocities; the militarization of gendered bodies and the impact of gender-based violence in armed conflict.

Finally, we will reflect on the gendered aspects of women’s restructuring of economies in male absence, their resistance to political violence, and their role in peacekeeping and rebuilding societies after war. As we cover each theme, we will pay particular attention to what feminists have described as intersectionality and the continuum of violence, from the “private” to the “public” sphere, from the militarization of everyday living to overt violent conflict. In addition, we will pay attention to whether different approaches to tackling gender inequality in South Asian contexts have been effective.

Assignments for the course include submissions that identify, assess, and integrate arguments based on the week’s readings; an in-class midterm assignment; in class pop quizzes; and a final paper. Additionally, students will be assessed on their preparation for the week’s class through attendance, participation and in-class presentations.

Overview

In this course, we will aim to impart agency to states, insurgents, aid agencies, and civilians in narratives of post-conflict politics. Specifically, we will explore various cases from around the world to think about the following questions:

- What are the problems of accountability and issues of individual responsibility in times of war? How have they been dealt with in response to historical conflicts of global significance?

- What are the current principles of accountability and mechanisms of transitional justice for enforcing these principles, including truth and reconciliation commissions, international criminal tribunals, and legal actions by third-party countries? 

- Does international aid help states to protect civilians, engage in hearts and minds, or build military coercive capacities?

- How do states that receive peacekeeping to end conflict fare differently in terms of long-term violent outcomes than those that don’t?

- Why do some rebel groups translate into political parties, while others don’t? What are the impacts of insurgent political participation on post-conflict democracy?

- What are some domestic obstacles to peacekeeping, reconstruction, and justice? How do conflict-affected groups draw boundaries between re-traumatization and accountability in the absence of state processes?

courseTitle: Landscapes, Sports, and Modernity: A Global History of Mountains and Mountaineering
description:
Landscapes, Sports, and Modernity: A Global History of Mountains and Mountaineering [HIS-3524/ ES-3224/ SOA-3105] [HIS-3524/ ES-3224/ SOA-3105-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Churiwala Garg [gaurav.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Most people today find mountains to be beautiful, majestic, and, serene. In contemporary imaginations, mountains are essential for the planet’s survival and indeed our own physical and mental health. But this was not always the case. In pre-modern Europe, for example, mountains were either ignored or depicted in literature as ugly deformities that scarred the Earth’s surface. Why did Europeans think of mountains as ugly? How, when, and why did their aesthetic imaginations change to a point where someone like the celebrated polymath John Ruskin could write that “mountains are the beginning and the end of all scenery”? How did European perceptions of mountains differ from that of the peoples and traditions of South Asia and elsewhere? And what role has South Asian history played in shaping modern human relationships with the mountains?

This course will take students on a journey from early Asia and pre- modern Europe, to the eighteenth-century when the Alps emerged as objects of adventure, veneration, and scientific experimentation, which in turn, kickstarted two new modern practices— mountain tourism and the world’s most literary sport, mountaineering. This course will then explore how these practices were deeply imbricated with colonialism, nationalism, fascism, and masculinity in the nineteenth and the twentieth centuries. The course will end in the late twentieth century where it will focus on commercialization of mountaineering and on issues pertaining to non-European modernity. In other words, this course will take students on a journey from a stage in human history where mountains were at best the abode of gods and spirits, and, at worst, ugly deformities, to a stage where there are now “traffic jams” on Mount Everest.

Focused on the Alps and the Himalaya, this interdisciplinary course will offer a new and exciting vantage point for learning about several fundamental issues and concepts in history and the humanities. Students will learn how scholars in the humanities have rehabilitated mountains as a key terrain where modernity is performed, its limits are exposed, and occasionally transcended. They will also learn about the extent to which our knowledge of the world is framed from the perspective of those who live in the “lowlands.” Overall, this course will motivate students to think of the history of human interactions with mountains as vital for making sense of what it means to be modern, and, for understanding how we got there.

Overview

Climate change has played a critical role in shaping the biological diversity in our planet. This course aims to introduce participants to the effects of climate change to biotic diversity, biogeography and human evolution focusing specifically on:

a. evolution and diversity in the last few million years, and

b. the contribution of genetics and genomics in understanding the evolution of natural populations during this period.

A significant portion is devoted towards introducing participants to the concepts and methods of population genetics, phylogenetics, molecular ecology, archaeogenetics/genomics etc. including elements of ancient DNA genomics and its application in understanding biotic evolution under climate change.

The course aims to equip students with conceptual and methodological knowhow of related evolutionary research and both case studies and hands-on exercises will be frequently used in this regard.

Students will learn how climate change has shaped the biodiversity on earth over a period of a billion years, with special focus on the evolution of current biodiversity. They will also learn how genomic data can be used to understand these associations. With the help of games and hands-on sessions, students will perform these analyses to understand the impact of climate change.

Overview
Why draw? What do we draw? What do we draw from? Who do we draw for? What is the worth of a drawing? What is the relevance of drawing, today?
This course examines the intersections between drawing and text, drawing and painting, drawing and photography, drawing and video, drawing and performance, and drawing and popular culture. In thinking of the everyday through the prism of theatrical reality, the course encourages inquiry about how drawings and the act of drawing itself is a dialogue about provisionality, uncertainty, and change. How do artists and artistic explorations address issues of meaning-making and shared history, politics, and culture? How do repetition, layering, overlapping, erasure, and incision transform an image, leading to alternative perspectives about how we perceive and engage with the known? How can we tell the same story in different material and socio-cultural contexts? Recognizing the importance of contradictions, ambiguity, and serendipity as integral to meaning-making processes, students have the flexibility to make interventions that can vary from poetic, polemic, dramatic, metaphorical, provocative, or incisive. You are encouraged to borrow from processes of scroll paintings, woodcut printmaking, comic books, experimental theatre, set design, photo performances, etc. 

Learning Outcomes


•Familiarity with histories of image making, reproduction, and consumption of images in popular media.
•Introduction to drawing as a visual language and a thinking medium with trans-disciplinary possibilities.

courseTitle: Is There A Modern Indian Literature?
description:
Is There A Modern Indian Literature? [ENG-4405/ CW-4405] [ENG-4405/ CW-4405-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Prakash Chaudhuri [amit.chaudhuri@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

I will use the Picador Book of Modern Indian Literature and a few other texts for this course, and also bring in cinema, art, and music as important entry-points into the 'modernity' I'm discussing here. The aim is to free pedagogy, reading, and creative-critical interaction with both Indian and European texts from the interpretative parameters of  'Western modernity', while also rejecting categories like 'non-Western modernity' that serve a merely corrective purpose. Instead, I wish to enquire afresh into the journey of literary and artistic modernity, using writing from India as my starting-point. I also plan to bring in some material from outside India – the stories of Junichiro Tanizaki, for instance.  The question in the course title is one I asked myself as I began putting together the anthology I mention above in the late 1990s. How was one to conceive of a tradition called 'Indian literature'? Was it the total of the various literatures of India? Or was there another way of exploring this category? It was a time when the Indian novel in English and the idea of 'postcolonial literature' had begun to dominate. How did the modernist and avant garde trajectories of literatures in the Indian languages fit into these relatively recent categorisations? One of my own reasons for rethinking and enlarging the frame had to do with my affinities with modernism as a reader and writer, affinities that seemed out of place post-Midnight's Children, but not so out of place within the experimental histories of modern Indian literatures themselves. 

 

The use of the word 'modern' was, and is, deliberate, to point to developments that the term 'postcolonial' doesn't address. The texts we'll read here would follow, without too much narrow systematising, ‘Indian literature’ and the way its emergence from the late nineteenth century in various languages embodied the trajectory of modernity, modernism, the avant garde, and formal preoccupations in India. The course means to question the largely theme-driven, Anglophone parameters of the ‘postcolonial’ that have been with us for some decades now.

Overview

Course Code: VA-3014/ SOA-3104/ HIS-3813-1
Level: 1000/2000/3000
Prerequisites: None

Course Description:
This course is an introduction to the architecture, sculpture and paintings of Buddhist temples and monasteries in the Western Himalayas, with a focus on extant sites in Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh. We will study major sites of art historical and cultural importance, while tracing their roots and interconnections to developments in art, religion, and aesthetics in Kashmir, Bihar and Tibet. The course focuses on studying monasteries and temples through their geographical location, their usage, and changes in structure and style in response to religious and socio-political developments as well as changes in local ecological conditions. The artistic strategies employed, the material used in making paintings and sculptures will be explored in relation to their geographic, architectonic and spatial contexts as well as the ritual requirements.

The course emphasises the importance and processes of place-making through history, mythology and local belief systems, and how these impact the relationship of communities with sites. We will also study the transformations that occur when sacred material culture is moved from its site of usage in the Himalayas to museum contexts. The course includes field trips to contemporary Buddhist sites in Delhi.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students:
· Will be conversant with major Buddhist temples and monasteries in Tibet, Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh, as well as early sites in the Kashmir Valley.
· Will have the ability to ‘read’ sites as architectonic spaces, and study the architecture, sculptures and paintings in relation to their usage.
· Will be able to identify major deities of the Tibetan Buddhist pantheon and identify stylistic features of early Tibetan Buddhist art.
· Will be familiar with developments in the art of the region in conjunction with changes in religion and socio-political contexts of patronage.
· Will be able to write concise art historical notes in the nature of museum catalogue entries.

Overview

Course description:

What is the violence of a line drawn upon a map? Or on a terrain? How are people produced by such mapping? What anxieties drive the imperial cartographic impulse? What pressures does terra nullis exert in situ? What do the bodies produced in mapped territories look like? What bodies exist in unmapped terrains? What is the relationship between wonder/amazement, and control/annihilation? Where do we locate ourselves as scholars reading these maps? What maps are visible when we visit the landscape? How are narratives produced against maps? How are histories made visible in terrain?

These questions will guide us as we traverse a theoretical terrain of writings on space and territory, and situate ourselves in specific historical moments of imperial mastery over space. We will cover a lot of ground temporally but our geographic focus will be South and East Asia. In this class we will develop skills in reading and understanding the genre of the academic monograph; in understanding how they relate to each other; and in analyzing the theoretical and methodological bases and trends of these works.

Overview

This course will bring together image making histories, concerns, theories and practices, based on photographic techniques and technologies. The course will comprehensively introduce proto-photographic methods and re-trace those with modern and contemporary material as well as some nineteenth and twentieth century cultural reactions and theories of photographic image-forms.

Considering its interdisciplinary nature, the media of photography will be introduced and explored through its contemporary usage as well as creative possibilities, bringing in perspectives from Art History, Visual Culture as well as artistic practice of the form.

Learning Outcomes

1. To recognize and locate photographic image-making language as a nuanced process with historical and theoretical underpinnings.

2.     To frame (reading) and craft (making) photographic practices from the discourse of technique, technology and aesthetics.

3.     To discern and gain confidence in situating and making of photographic image forms.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Details of Course Modules along with readings for every module:

Module 1: Proto-photography techniques and histories:

      Proto-photography and various techniques of image making:

Fading of a color or a surface due to light as reaction or creation of an image due to light sensitivity.
