Overview

This course introduces students to the role that ‘digital’ plays in how we read, analyze and create texts. Divided into three broad sections, we’ll first understand the new ways of reading that digital means offer. Then, we’ll consider creative productions such as digital games and instagram-films to study the storytelling possibilities that the digital offers. Finally, we’ll work on mini group projects making podcasts and visualizing data that help reconsider questions of representation and meaning-making.
These three rather practical sections will be set in the context of scholarly conversations that probe what the digital itself means, its colonial legacies, its gendered and capitalist underpinnings and the many new possibilities it offers to engage some perennial questions concerning cultural matters. Apart from written assignments, students will work on social digital annotations, mapping assignments, and storyboarding assignments. The course requires no prior familiarity with digital skills.

courseTitle: Studies in World Literature: African Modernities
description:
Studies in World Literature: African Modernities [ENG-3304] [ENG-3304-1]

Faculty Name
S Satish Kumar [s.kumar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

"Whether it be in the urban dystopias of Wakanda in the Black Panther films or in the sinister brooding forest landscapes of Ghana that become the mise-en-scene for staging the brutal violence of West African armed insurgencies in Beasts of No Nation, representations of “Africa” in contemporary “global” media often tend to reduce the complex and diverse lived realities of the peoples of this continent to mythic binaries of victimhood and resilience. This course attempts to unpack such an “Image of Africa”, as Chinua Achebe famously described it, through a closer examination of African literary modernities and the larger colonial and postcolonial histories of African nations around the time of their formations as independent sovereign states. Focusing primarily on the novel as a marker of and vehicle for the “modern” in African literary cultures, with the example of writers such as Ayi Kwei Armah, Assia Djebar, Camara Laye and Ama Ata Aidoo, we will be working towards understanding the experiential pluralities of colonization and postcoloniality that underscore African literary modernities."

courseTitle: Revealed Texts: The Qurʾan and its Late Antique Environment
description:
Revealed Texts: The Qurʾan and its Late Antique Environment [ENG-2106] [ENG-2106-1]

Faculty Name
Sarah Yona Zweig [sarah.zweig@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Late Antique Arabia has often been viewed as an ‘empty Ḥijāz’, culturally remote from the religious and political centres of the 7th century. However it is important to remember that the Qurʾan, while being the foundational scripture of one of the world’s largest religions, is also an important historic and literary document from Arabia of this time. In this course, we will explore the emergence of the Qurʾan (from Arabic qurʾān, ‘reading’ or ‘recitation’) and read it as a religious, historic and literary document -firmly situated within the cultural and historical milieux of Late Antiquity (ca. 3rd - 8th century CE). This course will introduce you to two exegetical worlds, the historical-critical study of the Qurʾan and Islamic exegesis (tafsīr). Notwithstanding their different approaches, premises and biases, they both share a fundamental commitment to close and patient reading, and an enduring fascination with the text of the Qurʾan. The initial segment of the course will focus on tracing the Qurʾan's origins within its historical context. We will delve into the intertextuality of Qurʾanic narratives and their Jewish and Christian counterparts. In the second part of the course we will read together excerpts from the 18th chapter of the Qurʾan, called Sūrat al-Kahf, accompanied by the seminal commentary known as the Tafsīr al-Jalālayn (15 th century CE). Sūrat al-Kahf is a particularly fitting since it offers a unique window into the rich literary worlds of Late Antiquity. Within its verses, a diverse collage of characters, motifs, and narratives unfolds, ranging from enigmatic sleeping youths and the prophet Moses to Alexander’s Doppelgänger Dhū l-Qarnayn.

courseTitle: Solitude and Community in Premodern Literature
description:
Solitude and Community in Premodern Literature [ENG-2308] [ENG-2308-1]

Faculty Name
Aparna Chaudhuri [aparna.chaudhuri@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course investigates the premodern history of solitariness, as a condition and experience, and its intellectual and emotional ramifications, among them self-discovery, contemplation of God, creative inspiration, and loneliness. Readings are drawn from monastic literature, Arthurian romance, classical and medieval philosophy, Shakespeare, and the metaphysical poets. We will also explore the oppositions and overlaps of solitude with community, and the representations, in literature, of being alone amongst other people, or finding counterintuitive community in the very experience of solitude

Reading Theory [ENG-3320] [ENG-3320-1]

Faculty Name
Madhavi Menon [menon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This class will follow the literary trajectory of theory by reading the literary texts with which theorists have formulated their theories. Equally, we will read theory as it engages with the literature that
has occasioned it. We will examine the boundary between so-called primary and secondary texts. Might we be able to obfuscate the hierarchical relation between the two? Thinking about
“reading” in the most capacious sense, this course will engage with the multiple layers of textuality that make up the world in which we live. What is the relation between literature and
theory? How do we get ideas? And how do these ideas allow us to engage the worlds in which we live? In this course, we will put together literary texts and theoretical essays on those literary
texts to think of theory as both the subject and object of reading: reading both as something that theory does and that can be done to theory.

Chemistry for beginners [CHM-0124] [CHM-0124-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Asthana [deepak.asthana@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Chemistry for Beginners is designed to be suitable for students from science as well as non-science background. This is an introductory course that focuses on development of a conceptual understanding of the fundamental principles of chemistry. It serves the purpose of giving students a solid and diverse introduction to the discipline. Various topics that will be covered include the atomic structure, atomic orbitals & electronic configurations, periodicity of elemental properties such as electronegativity, ionization energies and their impact, radioactivity, principles of acid/base theories, pH, buffers, acid-base indicators, empirical and molecular formulae, chemical bonding, molecular geometry, etc. The course objective is for students to gain competency (in recognizing concepts and problem solving) in basic areas of general chemistry.

No Pre-requisite for this course.

Course Contents: The topics that will be covered are as following-

Structure of the Atom and Elemental Properties

  • Bohr model of the atom
  • Orbitals, n, l, m and s quantum numbers and their significance
  • Complete electronic configuration of atoms
  • Periodicity: Size of atoms and ions, electron affinity and ionization energy
  • Radioactivity: Nuclear fission, nuclear fusion, critical mass; Kinetics of radioactive decay; Half-life and average life period; Applications of radioactivity (isotope dating, nuclear medicine)

Chemical Bonding: General Concepts 

  • Empirical and molecular formulae
  • Ionic Bonds
  • Lattice energies and how it is influenced by ionic size and charge
  • The octet rule and how it can be used to write ionic compounds and covalent molecules.
  • Covalent Bonds: How covalent bonds are formed
  • The VSEPR model and how it is used to predict molecular shapes
  • Concept of Hybridization 

Basic Chemical Properties

  • Solubility/miscibility rules
  • Principles of acid/base theories, pH, buffers, acid-base indicators
  • Oxidation-Reduction Reactions
  • Types of chemical reactions: Substitution, addition, and elimination
  • Basic understanding of organic chemistry: Functional groups, classes of compounds and IUPAC nomenclature system

 

Learning Outcomes

As this course covers the fundamental principles and laws of chemistry, upon completion, students should be able to demonstrate an understanding of the fundamental chemical laws, and the concepts as needed in higher level chemistry courses as well as other topics where knowledge of chemistry is expected.

courseTitle: Religious Life and Pre-Modern Women’s Writing
description:
Religious Life and Pre-Modern Women’s Writing [ENG-4123] [ENG-4123-1]

Faculty Name
Alexandra Cassatt Verini [alexandra.verini@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Books like Kate Bolick’s Spinster: Making a Life of One’s Own (2015) have received attention for highlighting women, mainly from the early twentieth century, who chose to live on their own terms. However, long before the modern desire for “a room of one’s own,” women were already involved in rejecting the bonds of marriage and claiming their own spaces. These were not best-selling authors but women who chose lives that were dedicated to God. From Catholic nuns to Sufi saints, medieval women in disparate parts of the globe found agency, community and fulfillment in single lives. Perhaps not surprisingly, the choice to live attached to God, either in community or in solitude, resulted in some of the earliest women’s writing. 

 

This course takes a global approach to writing and criticism that emerges out of medieval women’s religious callings, from the letters of Hildegard von Bingen to the lyrics of Mechthild of Magdeburg to the vakhs of Lal Ded, this course aims to track how devotion to god also constituted a refusal of heteronormativity. We will examine medieval writings alongside contemporary feminist, queer and theological theory to discern how celibate religious life, often lived in communities of other women, shaped medieval women’s literary culture. We will examine how the writings that emerge from these devotional ascetic contexts framed women’s relationships with God, with themselves, with each other and with the world and how these writings might offer us new frameworks for understanding gender, sexuality, and refusal today.

courseTitle: An Empire of Tales: The Alexander Narratives of the Ancient World
description:
An Empire of Tales: The Alexander Narratives of the Ancient World [ENG-4144] [ENG-4144-1]

Faculty Name
Sarah Yona Zweig [sarah.zweig@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Alexander the Great is one of the most iconic figures of the Ancient World. Each age and culture makes its own Alexander. Depicted as prophet and proto-Jesus or demi-God and demon, each Alexander mirrors the spirit and desires of the host culture. Following in the footsteps of Alexander we will travel through time and space, traversing the width of Eurasia and two millennia in tales. Together with Alexander we will encounter topless Amazons and nudist Brahmins, venture into the Land of Darkness and search for the Source of Life. Our class will be an excursion of intrepid explorers who venture into unknown (literary) territories. In the course of this journey we will read excerpts from the Bible, Plutarch, Josephus, the Babylonian Talmud, the Quran and the adaptations of the Greek Alexander Romance in Syriac, Ge’ez, Persian and the languages of mediaeval Europe. We will analyse the transformation of Alexander’s legends in visual culture from manuscript illuminations to their depictions on the screen. We will read texts in fine-grained detail and also learn to zoom out for an overview of the developments of narratives and motifs. Though we will study literature on Alexander in translation, we will supplement our reading with references to the source languages and their literary contexts. In the course of the seminar you will be exposed to topics in historical criticism and narratological studies — What is a stemma? What is an Urtext? How and why do motifs transform?

courseTitle: Dialectics against Despair: Frankfurt School Critical Theory
description:
Dialectics against Despair: Frankfurt School Critical Theory [ENG-4844] [ENG-4844-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will serve as an introduction to the circle of thinkers loosely affiliated with Frankfurt School Critical Theory, in particular Theodor Adorno, Walter Benjamin, Max Horkheimer, and also their sometime inspiration, sometime adversary Georg Lukács. “Dialectics against despair” might be a surprising title for a course that focuses on a philosophy of negativity articulated by a group of thinkers the later Lukács famously dismissed as the “Grand Hotel Abyss.” But the versions of dialectical thought coming out of the Frankfurt School are not simply about wallowing (or reveling) in negativity for negativity’s sake. They are instead a way of keeping thought in motion and preserving a critical potential against a status quo that is perfectly able to assimilate even what appears to stand outside and in opposition to it, both in the realms of activism and theory. Perhaps, as Adorno says, “wrong life cannot be lived rightly,” but dialectical thinking can at least be a means to begin to glimpse something better, however vague and fleeting that “something better” must remain. Such thinking, Adorno argues, is at once the simplest and the most impossible thing, but is ultimately “the only philosophy which can be responsibly practised in the face of despair.” In this class we will follow this line of thinking from the 1920s through the 1960s, exploring arguments about the status of art in an era of industrial mass culture, the failure of revolution and the catastrophe of fascism, the domination of nature, and also, for the record, false happiness peddled under late capitalism. Through readings and discussion we will situate their writings historically against the backdrop of Nazism, exile, and ultimately post-war conservative restoration, while also keeping an eye on what they might offer us in our own thinking about culture.

Detecting Writing [CT-2482] [CT-2482-1]

Faculty Name
Alexandra Cassatt Verini [alexandra.verini@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We might think of writing as the setting down of predetermined thoughts; but, in fact, writing serves, more often and more productively, as a way of figuring out what we think. By writing (and revising and revising again) we ask ourselves questions and investigate our opinions and those of others. In this way writing, is something like solving a puzzle or even a crime. Just as literary detectives ask questions about motive, means and opportunity to discern who the killer is in a thriller, when we write, we ask and answer a multitude of questions to solve our own set of mysteries.    

By taking detective fiction as its subject, this Critical Thinking Seminar will examine works such as the short stories of Edgar Alan Poe and Agatha Christie and the 2015 film Talvar with the aim to train you in skills necessary to the process of reading and writing about literature. Each of the critical skills—from close reading to developing an argument to forming paragraphs— is paired with a work of detective fiction to help you consider that skill and give you topics for writing assignments. In addition to reading detective fiction and watching a few detective films, we will read some secondary works about the genre of detective fiction. The goal of the course overall is to hone your skills in writing about literature by examining a genre of literature that mirrors the process of writing itself.

Bad Literature: Studying Cultural Tastemaking [CT-2485] [CT-2485-1]

Faculty Name
Tanvi Chowdhary [tanvi.chowdhary_phd21@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor: Tanvi Chowdhary

Email: tanvi.chowdhary_phd21@ashoka.edu.in

Critical Thinking Seminar

Title – Bad Literature: Studying Cultural Tastemaking

What constitutes the broad, loosely defined idea of a bad book? Is it a text which is dense, complicated, and difficult to read – or a text which is frivolous, and silly, and romantic? Is a bad book one that often has themes we don’t agree with, or racist and misogynistic representations of characters? Are they texts that are sold purely with commercial purposes in mind? Put simply, what do we think of when we think of Bad Books?

Depending on class, position, level of education, or something as simple as the access to a library – our definitions of what is or isn’t bad literature changes. This course is an exploration of discourses about Bad Books, the critical history of judgement behind them, and an analysis of contemporary tastemaking. To pass critical judgement on art is not something done in isolation – it often signals social class and affiliation, in-group knowledge that is often designed to include and exclude. Additionally, Bad Books are usually considered so because they are judged largely as commodities, as opposed to art, which is a distinction frequently drawn in the process of tastemaking. Moreover, what is considered bad literature, often hides a wealth of reading practices of its own – the most relevant example of which is fanfiction, which operates on a digital economy quite separate from the publishing industry. Through this course, we will try to understand the wealth of reading practices that are the basis for the tastemaking that might deem a text such as Twilight as trash, and one like Normal People as literature.

Learning Outcomes

Over the course of this semester, I would like you to think about the kinds of biases that go into taste making – and the nature of studying literature as a whole. Since a lot of the texts we study in literature are broadly considered “good” reading (your personal and real opinions on Shakespeare, Austen, or any of the rest are welcome), it might be useful to look at literature slant, from an angle that we generally do not have the privilege to spend a lot of time thinking about.

Moreover, I would like this course to be one to bring your guiltiest pleasures, the texts you find most difficult to talk about in an academic environment – and hopefully decode what it is that you enjoy about these texts. Enjoyment is not, after all, something without theoretical force – and to have fun with reading is perhaps one of the rare affordances of studying literature that we can play with.

Novel Worlds [ENG-3368] [ENG-3368-1]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The most modern of genres, the novel is the book of life. It reflects worlds within and without; it registers the shifts of history and culture; it is at once escape, homecoming, and homelessness. Novels can contain revolutions (in both senses of the word 'contain') even as they redefine consciousness and personhood. They  examine reality in ways that include elements of the scientific or the philosophical, but through a distinctive mode of imaginative consideration. The novel is a shapeshifting, open-ended genre.

In this course, we will discuss the ways in which the novel and the world make, remake, and unmake each other. We will consider the history of the novel, including anachronisms and ruptures; we will think about the form of the novel, including departures and deformations, and we'll think about ways in which novels themselves reflect on acts of reading and interpretation. Our discussions and written work will take in politics and affect, aesthetics and materiality. Our focus will for the most part remain on fiction from the nineteenth century and twentieth centuries, with a few works by twenty-first century writers: canonical realist fiction (by writers such as Jane Austen, Elizabeth Gaskell, and Charles Dickens), more experimental literary fiction (including works by Virginia Woolf,  Salman Rushdie, and Paul Beatty), and some works of genre fiction (horror, detective fiction, science fiction, and so on) that are yet to be decided. As we read theories of the novel alongside these narrative works, we will think about the ways in which novels encourage us to get out of our skins, inhabit other ways of becoming and being, travel through time and space, and encounter new universes--or, as we like to call them in this course, novel worlds.

 

Learning Outcomes

1. To develop an understanding of the novel that takes in history, form, and theory.

2. To develop the skills of close reading and analytical writing.

Overview

This course will focus on the intersections between Gender and Psychology across various domains. We will start with theoretical concepts of Gender formulations in psychology, history of gender struggle and rights movements, methodology and ethical issues in gender psychology research, and proceed towards exploring other psychological variables in gender. Throughout, the instructor will strive for a balance of introducing the class to literature that is cross-culturally pertinent.  We will critically engage with psychological literature that have dealt with essentialization of gendered attributes, sexually dimorphic models that dominate evolutionary psychology and biomedical research spaces, as well as psychological literature that focus on gender similarity and investigate the reasons behind gender differences in psychological constructs and attributes. We will discuss why intersectionality has emerged as an important perspective in gender research. This course is, expressly, not just for womxn students. It is encouraged that men enroll for this class as well, because this class will be geared towards a discussion of ALL genders within a framework of psychological thought, and no discussion on gender is complete if  half the population is excluded from it.   This is an advanced seminar styled course with weekly discussions and flipped classrooms employed  for most of the course, with didactic lectures only being a part of the entire 90 minute long class duration.

Overview

Computer Organization and Systems (CS-2710), Spring 2025

Understanding the principles of computer organization and systems lies at the foundation of computer design. The aim of this course is two-fold: to introduce (i) the basics of computer organization and architecture (COA), and (ii) the fundamentals of operating systems (OS). In the COA-part, students will learn how programs written in a high-level programming language are executed on a physical machine. What is the hardware-software interface? Does the underlying “organization” of physical resources define the “architecture” of a machine, or vice-versa? Which factors need to be considered for designing the Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) so that the performance of the machine is optimized? We will highlight techniques for designing instruction set, and pipelining mechanism for the best utilization of hardware. Special emphasis will be given on RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer). In the latter part, students will learn how OS acts as an intermediary between computer hardware and the user for running applications. How the computer's resources, such as the CPU, memory, storage, and input/output devices are managed to ensure that everything runs smoothly and efficiently. How multiple processes run on the same CPU without conflict?

During the course we will walk through a selection from the following topics:

Introduction: Evolution of computers, hierarchical design of computer systems, hardware/software interface. Models of computation, overall system organization: Basic functional blocks of a computer - CPU, memory, I/O subsystems, control unit. Instruction set architecture (ISA): registers, execution cycle, addressing modes.  CPU Performance Equation, Amdahl’s Law. RISC versus CISC machines.

Instruction sets: Introduction to MIPS: operations, operands, and op-codes; MIPS assembly language.

Computer arithmetic: Number systems – Fixed and floating-point binary number representation; Integer addition and subtraction, design of arithmetic logic unit (ALU):

Processor design and Pipelining: Data path and control unit design, simple pipeline, hazards.

Operating systems: Elementary concepts of an OS, process management, inter-process communication, threads and concurrency, CPU scheduling, case studies.

Process synchronization: Synchronization tools, the critical-section problem, semaphores, deadlocks.

Memory management: Memory hierarchy; Cache architecture; Main memory; Virtual memory.

Multi-Core and Multi-Processing (if time permits): SISD, MIMD, SIMD, Vector processing; Multithreading, Shared-memory multiprocessors; Graphics processing units; Clusters and cloud; Multiprocessor network topologies.

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course, students are expected to learn how a complete processor is designed in order to support an instruction set architecture as well as how the OS runs in the background overseeing all operations.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Suggested Reading:

1. D. A. Patterson and J. L. Hennessy, Computer Organization and Design - the Hardware Software Interface, 6th Edition, Elsevier, Morgan Kaufmann, 2021.

2. A. Silberschatz, P. B. Galvin, and G. Gagne, Operating System Concepts, Tenth Edition, Wiley, 2018.

Faculty Name

Overview

This course is an experimental attempt to bring together medicine, movies (as in all moving images) and literature (fiction/nonfiction/comics). It is an attempt to cross- fertilize and open up the possibility of doing an anthropology of medicine by carefully examining aesthetic objects such as literature and movies, and to introduce those who may be interested in movies and literature to the anthropology of medicine.

There are roughly four provisional modules: epidemics/pandemics; trans-corporeality; psychiatry; pharmaceuticals. Or the movement of germs/viruses, body parts, mind/consciousness/souls, drugs/vaccines. Unlike possibly other courses, we intend, in large part, to shift the emphasis to the Anglophone world, particularly the United States of America, as the analytical object in an attempt to wean students away from India as an ethnographic object and towards a country with an abiding religious undercurrent, although it is formally a secular democracy and ostensible trend-setter of the contemporary world. This is partly to emphasize that it may be interesting to make the US rather than India labour under the trope of religion, and, thereby, befuddle received anthropological categories.

We intend to do this by starting with a war game called Dark Winter run by the Department of Homeland Security in the US. Played purportedly in “real time”, with a sitting US senator playing the President of the US, it simulates a smallpox attack on the American Homeland. We will pair this with a movie on the Ebola virus, which escapes the nuking of an African village and arrives in the US piggy-backing on exotic pets shipped from the Congo to California. Against the backdrop of the lived experience of the pandemic, and the just concluded presidential election run as a “Book of Revelation horrors”, we will ask if epidemic imaginaries are harbingers of the apocalypse – as is the case with climate change – and how religion, especially late-nineteenth century American Dispensationalism, informs epidemics and pandemics. We may buttress this by drawing attention to the apocalyptic novels of the Left Behind thriller series, which by 2017 had not only sold 65 million copies but had spawned a mini industry of movies, video games, etc.

We then intend to traverse the world of transplants: body parts, embryos, gene editing, double mastectomies; then move up the body to the ineffable entity called consciousness, which seems to perpetually slip away and evade capture by either medicine, philosophy, or religion, except perhaps by the Amerindians who seem to know where it is as they appear to make trans-corporeal soul transfers to make their dogs dream better; and finally, end with the pharmaceutical industry: one that promises redemption from pain and suffering, and even the possibility, through psychedelics, of tangible meetings with God; and, in the bargain, seems to deliver addiction and iatrogenesis.

We invite students to step up and co-curate this experimental and neoteric effort by bringing visual and literary material to the table so that the modules and the trajectory sketched above may be brought to fruition. What is Globalization? [SOA-3147] [SOA-3147-1]

Overview

What is globalization? How do anthropologists/sociologists study global phenomena? The concept of globalization has two distinct meanings. On the one hand, globalization denotes an ever-intensifying connectivity between societies, cultures, and regions across planet Earth. On the other hand, globalization denotes a normative project, one that empowers multilateral alliances and international law for governing cross-border connectivity. While scholars and the world public increasingly speak of the demise of globalization in the normative sense, societies are ever more connected, and transnational flows and crises are faster and more intense each day.

This course introduces students to the main concepts, definitions, and theories that shape the scholarly conversation over globalization. However, the course is not merely theoretical. We will read essays on methods and examples of empirical research that inspire anthropologists and sociologists to design research proposals to study global phenomena in their interactions with local and national scales of social activity. By the end of the semester, students will develop a research proposal to study a global phenomenon of their preference by applying the main ideas and frameworks in the syllabus.

Overview

Re-Enchanting Expertise: Affecting the Rational [SOA-3148] [SOA-3148-1]

Overview

More than a century ago, sociologist Max Weber declared that the expanded rationality of modernity had disenchanted the world. Since the Enlightenment, “mysterious incalculable forces” have been replaced by accountable and calculable forces. Logs, metrics, models, and experiments replaced God, myth, and magic to render the world transparent. Yet, even as colonialism expanded Enlightenment values beyond Europe, the grotesque and the mythical survived the test of time. New and old enchantments, from raging wildfires to opulent godmen and shamans, proliferate modern society.  This course will explore how our social worlds and institutions have been shaped by this overarching narrative of modernity- disenchantment. We will also examine how subjectivity, the affective, and the mythical are not rationality’s evil other but rather are integral to its survival. Could re-enchanting scientific progress produce new forms of expertise in our modern world?

courseTitle: Anthropology of Religion: Animism, Hylozoism, Panpsychism, Techno-Sacramentalism
description:
Anthropology of Religion: Animism, Hylozoism, Panpsychism, Techno-Sacramentalism [SOA-3150/ SOA-6125] [SOA-3150/ SOA-6125-1]

Faculty Name
Harish Naraindas [harish.naraindas@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is religion in the anthropological canon? Why has religion been addressed, either tacitly or explicitly, in conjunction with magic and science? Are magic, religion and science epochal moments in mankind’s evolutionary ascent, or are they coeval in time? How has anthropology, starting with Tylor, Frazer, Durkheim and Malinowski, attempted to come to terms with it? Does the religious history of these European thinkers, with the Reformation as a watershed, have a bearing on why they have been addressed together? Or were they led to invoke the category of magic through a colonial encounter with cultures – which the New World Encyclopaedia charmingly calls “newly contacted societies'' – that they designated primitive, which in fact is the title – Primitive Culture – of Edward Tylor’s celebrated work of 1871. The work where Tylor christens such cultures as animistic, thus setting in motion the formal study of religion through the concept of animism: a concept that inaugurates and virtually sets in stone the distinction between Us and Them, or between European and non-European cultures, or between the European past and its present, or between an enchanted, magical, pre-modern and primitive world, and presumably a disenchanted, secular and modern world. It is through the concept of animism, along with its cognate concepts of hylozoism and panpsychism, that this course will trace the genealogy of the study of religion and interrogate its consequences. We will, after running through the canon from Tylor to Evans Pritchard, examine contemporary but “conventional” ethnographies in “primitive” or “polytheistic” settings such as Vitebsky’s “Dialogues with the Dead” in Orissa, or Sax’s religion, affliction and healing in the Himalayas. We will then look at Ram’s “Fertile Disorder”, and her “provocation of the modern”, that extends and attempts to call this trajectory into question. We will pursue this questioning by turning to witchcraft in post-war Germany, and then turn to the fusion of magic, religion and science – or “techno- sacramentalism” – in twenty-first century German Hospitals. We will then, through Keith Thomas’ work, mark the presumed decline of animism and magic, not in primitive cultures but in European Catholicism, through the assiduous work of the Protestants and their Religion, thus offering us a different vantage point on why animism/magic/superstition were so important to Tylor (a Quaker) and Frazer (a Presbyterian) in framing their theories that the discipline has been historically saddled with. We will end the course by asking – through the “animistic turn” and Jason Storm’s work – whether the supposed exit of animism, which presumably inaugurates European modernity and sets it apart from the non-European world, spawning in the bargain ethnographic objects and explanatory moves, is indeed true, and, if not, how are we to rethink the future of not only religion as an object of enquiry, but of our very disciplines and their founding premises?

courseTitle: Foundations of Modern China: The Qing Dynasty in World History
description:
Foundations of Modern China: The Qing Dynasty in World History [CHI-3205/ HIS-3535] [CHI-3205/ HIS-3535-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Modern China is among the world’s two largest countries by population, two largest by economy, and its fourth largest by geographical size. As a state, it follows centuries of imperial dynasties whose complex legacies it sometimes claims and sometimes rejects. In the last two hundred years, China has experienced some of the most dramatic social and cultural transformations and some of the most violent conflicts of any region of the world. As it was incorporated into an international system dominated by Europe and the United States, it became an integral part of global history in new ways and, increasingly, a shaper of that history. Often imagined as a monolith, it is in fact deeply heterogeneous, home to multiple languages and ethnicities, countless local traditions, millions of adherents of major world religions, and sizable foreign communities. Today, China is the site of crucial questions concerning geopolitics, the environment, global health, and human rights. At the same time, it has inherited and continues to produce immense bodies of art and literature, distinctive belief systems and intellectual movements, and delicious food. In these and other capacities, it also informs the identities of millions of people of Chinese ancestry living around the world.

            This course examines the Qing Dynasty (1644-1912) and the early days of the Republic of China. It makes reference to Tibetan, Taiwanese, diasporic Chinese, and global histories as well. It offers systematic coverage of Qing expansion and crisis, Qing culture, encounters with Asia and the West, the emergence of nationalism, and the transition out of the dynastic state. In the process, it gives special attention to questions of race and ethnicity, gender, frontiers, global connections, and nation-building. Instead of a chronological overview of the Qing era, this class will deal with historical processes between 1644-1912 through the four themes of statecraft, agriculture and commerce, ethnicity, and gender. This course design emphasizes historical thinking skills (e.g. understanding causation, contingency, agency, anachronism, meaning, and so on) and highlights the voices of historical figures, both powerful and ordinary, through translated primary sources. No prior knowledge is required.

Learning Outcomes

Course Objectives

This course has two objectives. One is to develop productive familiarity with some of the most representative themes, questions, and sources associated with the study of Qing history. The other is to cultivate the ability to ask historical questions in an intellectually responsible and rigorous way. We will focus on skills of critical thinking, reading, and writing (including textual, contextual, conceptual, comparative, and synthetic analysis), as well as habits of reasonable, respectful, and inclusive discussion. By the end of this class you should be able to:

Summarize academic monographs in East Asian studies and introduce salient points in notes and in speech.

Draw connections between works to gain an overview of scholarly and historiographical debates in the study of Qing China.

Trace theoretical or methodological trends across multiple empirical contexts.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required Texts and key:

You are not required to purchase any materials for this course. All readings will be provided in PDF via email. Some weeks will list additional optional material, please reach out to me if you would like a copy of those texts.

In general, the books we are reading from most frequently are:

Morris Rossabi, A History of China, 1st edition (Wiley Blackwell, 2014). [HOC]

Pei-kai Cheng, Michael Lestz, and Jonathan D. Spence, The Search for Modern China: A Documentary Collection (New York: W.W. Norton & Co., 1999). [SMC]

David G. Atwill and Yurong Y. Atwill, Sources in Chinese History: Diverse Perspectives from 1644 to the Present (New York: Routledge, 2021). [SCH]

Wm. Theodore de Bary and Irene Bloom, eds., Sources of Chinese Tradition, 2nd edition (New York: Columbia UP, 2000). [SCT]

Optional Reference Text

A more detailed textbook that may be a useful reference for essay assignments is:

Jonathan D. Spence, The Search for Modern China, 3rd edition (New York: W.W. Norton & Co., 2012).

Advanced News Reporting [MS-2573] [MS-2573-1]

Faculty Name
Maya Mirchandani [maya.mirchandani@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Good journalism is an iterative process. Building on Introduction to News Reporting (MS-1101) that familiarizes students with journalism’s first principles and teaches them the very basics of journalistic writing, the Advanced News Reporting course aims to encourage students to learn how to look for their own stories, and develop their kernels of ideas into exploratory, rigorous and well crafted stories through practical exercises throughout the semester.

In a rapidly changing technological environment, students will also experiment with different formats of news dissemination and whether they prioritize information accuracy, context and ethics of news and newsworthiness. Through an analysis of the current news media landscape they will be able to learn the value of staying true to these tenets.

The classes will be conducted as part lecture, part editorial meeting and part fieldwork. Students are expected to arrive in class having read at least two of the day’s major newspapers and scoured through news websites that offer both text and video formats of news. Deadlines will be taken seriously, and any delays in story submissions will be penalized.

 

MS 1101 - Introduction to newswriting is a pre-requisite for this course. 

Learning Outcomes

The course will introduce students to the art of layering their news reports by exploring the intricacies and contradictions in the engagement between a free press, the public and government. Students will understand the concepts of news beats, and specialized reporting, developing contacts and sources, interviewing, and using data effectively as a research tool. They will learn to distinguish between hard news, features, and narrative journalism styles.

Students will also experiment with writing news for television and other audio visual formats online, as well as learn the importance and craft of “live reporting” in which social media is often used to communicate stories with a sense of urgency and immediacy. Students will complement written articles with multimedia tools in the process. Those who have taken audio visual production, sound or photography courses are encouraged to use those skills while working on their stories.

courseTitle: Though This be Madness: Theories of History-Writing
description:
Though This be Madness: Theories of History-Writing [HIS-5900] [HIS-5900-1]

Faculty Name
Aparna Vaidik [aparna.vaidik@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This graduate seminar  is inspired by the famous line in Shakespeare’s play Hamlet ‘“though this be madness, there is method in’t”. This line captures the bewildering number of methods that historians have conjured up or drawn on to practice their craft. We will read ten historical texts written over a period of 50 years (from 1960s to 2010s) that engage with historical processes and also conceptualize their method for studying the process. For instance, Robert Darnton's book on 'Mesmerism' examines an exotic theory of healing that immediately seized the imagination of the general populace. Darnton’s juxtaposes this to the utter failure of Rousseau's Social Contract in rousing the masses. The question he asks is: if the greatest political treatise of the age failed to interest many literate Frenchmen, what form of radical ideas suited their tastes? This question serves as a doorway into study of popular culture and, it also questions the general historical assumption that it is the works of big theorists that move history. Paul Feyeraband in his book Against Method takes the example of Galileo to make a case that science should have an anarchic method. He poses the apparently simple but not-so-innocuous question: How does science differ from witchcraft? He demonstrates how Galileo used rhetoric, propaganda, and various epistemological artifices  to support the heliocentric position. Agnes Heller, author of A Theory of History conceptualizes the idea of 'chance' as a significant element of historical method. She draws on Jules Verne’s book Captain Grant’s Children (1867), where the children find a bottle in a the belly of a shark. The bottle has a message which is wet and not fully decipherable. They find the lost ship (from which the bottle with the note came) completely by chance and not by piecing together the evidence. Similarly, Marshall Sahlins writes about the significance of 'co-incidence' and Carlo Ginzburg about 'conjecture' as central element of historical method. I am imagining this seminar as a lively conversation that we will have as we read and engage with these books. The objective is to think deeply about the historian’s craft and to understand one's own practice. Please join the course only if you are willing to read deeply and if you enjoy conversations.

Class Format: Each student is expected to ‘adopt’ two texts (one before the mid-term and one after) and come prepared to present the main questions the books raise, their arguments, the sources they draw on and the vantage point of the historian, and finally what they made of the text.

The books:

1. Robert Darnton, Mesmerism and the End of Enlightenment in France

2. Fann, K. T., 1970. Peirce’s Theory of Abduction, The Hague: Martinus Nijhoff]

3. Agnes Heller - A Theory of History

4. Lucien Febvre,  The Problem of Unbelief in the Sixteenth Century: The Religion of Rabelais

5. Paul Feyeraband - Against Method: Outline of an Anarchist Theory of Knowledge

6. Marc Ferro, Cinema and History

8. Carlo Ginsburg, History, Rhetoric, and Proof

courseTitle: Philosophy as a Way of Life
description:
Philosophy as a Way of Life [PHI-2109] [PHI-2109-1]

Faculty Name
Aditi Chaturvedi [aditi.chaturvedi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“There are nowadays professors of philosophy but not philosophers…yet philosophy is admirable to profess because it was once admirable to live.” In this course, we will take Thoreau’s words seriously and read a range of philosophical texts with an eye not just to mastering the language and methods of philosophy but also seeing why philosophy matters in our everyday lives. While contemporary philosophical practices might lead one to regard philosophy as a technical discipline concerned with theorizing about fundamental questions, many philosophers — the world over and acrosstime periods — have regarded it, instead, as a transformative practice. Seneca spoke disparagingly of those who taught us how to argue rather than how to live. For Montaigne, our duty was to compose our characters rather than books. The Buddhist eight-fold path was not a speculation of merely intellectual import, but intended as a guide for the right way to live. The arguments of the Analects were intended to indicate a path towards self-cultivation. In this course, we will study the various ways in which philosophy can be conceived of as a way of life. We will also consider whether such conceptions of philosophy can be valuable, or even defensible, in the twenty-first century. This is a course in comparative philosophy and we will study a range of philosophical traditions to learn how philosophy was — and can be — lived.

The Course

The study of the Middle East assumes huge significance as its turbulent politics today draws global attention. Vast parts of this world were integral to an expanding   Ottoman Empire that began its innings in the 13th century and survived until the first world war. It was this Ottoman world that left its indelible impression on the modern Middle East when the post war British mandates framed the region.

This course studies the making of the Ottoman Empire from the 13th to the beginning of the 18th centuries to offer historical insights to the making of the modern Middle East.  It focusses on the complex network of alliances, and forms of communication that sustained and reproduced empires in the pluralistic and diverse socio-cultural settings embraced by the early Ottomans. It discusses the making of Ottoman political sovereignty and economy in the early modern period in the backdrop of the many challenges faced by the Empire.

The course has a comparative edge, and encourages us to think about the deep cultural and intellectual affinities that the Ottoman empire had with the Mughals and the Safavids in India and Iran respectively. It throws light on how these trans- imperial entanglements help us under better the geo-politics of the modern Middle East world.

Week 3-4: The Early Ottomans: The idea of frontier and gazi.

Week 13 Ottoman court culture

Reading Persian Manuscripts [HIS-5015] [HIS-5015-1]

Faculty Name
Nadeem Aktar [nadeem.akhtar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is meant for Ashoka students who have successfully completed two years of Introductory Persian Courses at the University. The courses are designed particularly to equip PhD students in reading and interpreting historical texts for their research.

Classical Persian Texts and Contexts
Persian literature written before the nineteenth century differs from modern literature both in form and content. The language of classical Persian literature is replete with Arabic words and literary phrases. They also have rich literary embellishments and artistic expressions. All this makes these texts very different from modern Persian texts. This course introduces these classical Persian texts to the students. It trains them to analyse these texts from a literary point of view and to enhance their skill of reading them in their historical contexts. This course will help the students negotiate the texts, documents, and archival materials of medieval and early modern periods in their PhD research.  


Codicology
Museums, libraries, and archives are full of Persian manuscripts and documents which are treasure houses of information and knowledge about the past. These Persian texts were written in various scripts by scribes, artists, statesmen, poets, and writers. Aside from texts, there are also additional documentary material – like flyleaf, colophon, endorsements, and seals – that are useful to understand the past. Many of these texts are not legible and can be read only by experienced readers. One of the challenges of modern times is to discern these writings and make the texts legible and translate them into English or vernacular languages. Many of the manuscripts lying in archival collection are still waiting for their readers, editors, and translators. As such, they are hidden from the public domain. This course on codicology will train research students in reading these manuscripts and using them for historical and literary research.

Inscriptions
In medieval India, the usage of Persian language was not limited to the writings of administrative documents and literature; it was also used to write inscriptions on walls of forts, tablets of mosques, tombs, and gardens. Inscriptions in Persian language also adorned many swords, knives, armours, and cannons.  Coins minted by the rulers also bear inscriptions in Persian. Museums and archives have vast collections of such coins and artifacts. All these inscriptions comprise extremely valuable sources for historical research and can be read only by trained scholars. This course equips research students to read and interpret inscriptional records to decode the past. 

Learning Outcomes

The course enables PhD students of History to read and understand the Persian sources

Relevant Persian Manuscripts and sources to be used by the PhD students in their researches shall be taught in the classes.

description:
Cinemas of the World: Films, Movements and case Studies [MS-2093] [MS-2093-1]

Faculty Name
Monia Acciari [monia.acciari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Welcome everyone to Cinemas of the World. This course is a virtual journey across the world, to study, view, and curate films that have made an impact globally.  

This course examines key theoretical and critical concepts, as well as debates, that are essential for a comprehensive historical and contextual understanding of World Cinema. It emphasizes contemporary developments and case studies through specific films, regions, and/or directors. The current period is widely regarded by critics as a golden age for emerging "new cinemas," directors, and transnational trends, including popular exportable genres, new multicultural genres like migrant and accented cinema, "new" realisms, and "slow cinema." Recently, World Cinema Studies and Transnational Film Studies have emerged as distinct academic fields. The aim of this course is to provide you with a well-rounded understanding of the diverse range of World Cinemas beyond the structures of Hollywood, exploring the transnational and transcultural contexts of production, circulation, consumption, and reception of "World Cinema" films today. These aspects have been shaped by factors such as new digital technologies, the internet, global media convergence, economic and cultural globalization, and political transformations, all of which will be addressed in this course. Alongside a theoretical and analytical component, the course will also introduce you to practical notions of curatorship, to  understand how the exhibition industry works in relation to creative programmes of world cinema. Some of the key films we will study are from regions such as Africa, Italy, Iran, Korea, and China, among others.

Learning Outcomes

On completion of this course, students will be able to:

1. Gain an understanding of key theoretical and critical concepts, models and debates relevant to the study of both national cinemas and transnational developments within World Cinemas, and had opportunities to apply these. (Research Dossier, Curatorial programme, and audio-visual diary).

2. Engage in depth with selected film/cinema case studies (national, transnational, thematic/issue based, or director-focused). (Research Dossier and Curatorial programme).

3. Gain an informed sense of the institutional, economic, political, cultural and wider contextual issues around contemporary ‘World’ filmmaking (from questions of history, identity and representation to the impacts of globalisation and new technologies) and the ways in which these may shape the themes, style, production, circulation and reception of non-Hollywood ‘World Cinema’ films. (Research Dossier and Curatorial Programme).

4. Build competence in, selecting and applying relevant concepts, arguments and contextual understanding appropriately in (i) discussion and evaluation of trends, movements and/or case studies within World Cinema at national and transnational levels, and (ii) critical discussion and/or textual analysis of specific films. (Research Dossier and Curatorial programme).

5. Demonstrate a critical, practical and historically informed appreciation of the different ways in which film industries may be conceptualised in both national and transnational terms.

Grading Rubric

The course comprises of two assessments as follows:

1. Digital Research Dossier: Students are required to compile a research dossier, in form of presentation, that details the journey of a feature film which had a significant impact worldwide for its distribution strategies, exhibition history and production practices (pick one of the countries we are studying in this course). In relation to a film discuss one of the key themes debated that include notions of: national cinema, transnational and accented cinema Art cinema etc. (to be submitted in week 7). 

2. Curatorial Programme: The final assessment of this course is a creative production. The students are required to put together a viewing programme of international films, from a variety of world cinemas in which notions of: the national, the transnational, the postmodern etc. is narrativized through a curated digital catalogue for a public event. (to be completed and submitted at the end of the teaching term).

Understanding audio visual production [MS-1567] [MS-1567-1]

Faculty Name
Natasha Badhwar [natasha.badhwar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will introduce students to audio and video production at an introductory level. Through a series of viewings of historical and contemporary documentary films and readings, students will understand the formats, power and tools of audio visual communication, grasp basic concepts and terminology around production and be introduced to media ethics.

The course will explore the increasing predominance of visual media in contemporary life and the various ways in which traditional narrative forms of storytelling are being replaced by visual forms of storytelling in journalism, photojournalism, film, television, the internet, video games, anime, graphic novels, and advertising. Students will view and analyse films on the basis of  documentary modes as proposed by documentary theorist Bill Nichols - poetic, expository, observational, participatory, reflexive, and performative.

Students will receive basic training in professional video production and use of equipment, as well as post-production practices and software, with an emphasis on establishing effective communication and collaborative skills. Special emphasis will be paid on composition, light and texture in photography and its affective impact on the viewer. The use of movement, sound and transition techniques in editing will be observed and put into practice.

Through a series of practical exercises, they will learn low-budget production methodologies including basic studio production - and the many open-source software tools and platforms that can facilitate video production.

Learning Outcomes

Students will become familiar with the long arc of the history and development of audio-visual expression and the technologies that have enabled them.

They will learn about the power and resonance of audio-visual expression through guided exercises in components of photography, videography and video editing.

Faculty Name
Sameera Jain [sameera.jain@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview
Introduction to the Documentary
Encounters with reality: deconstructing and understanding non-fiction cinema
 
The course will unravel various dimensions of the documentary form as it has developed over time, till the present. We observe the nature of the document as it emerges in the documentary, analysing the binaries of subjectivity and objectivity, and the truth claim that much documentary practice asserts. Is documentary information and education? Or is it also activism, observation, experiment, poetry and art? Exploring several thematic preoccupations and narratives within the documentary, we discover the richness that the form holds. Discussing tropes that documentary often rests on, and conceptually navigating ethical, aesthetic aspects, the course examines the politics of representation.
 
The sessions will include viewing, critical analysis and participatory discussion. The course will culminate in student presentations on chosen aspects of documentary cinema. The presentations will be intensively mentored, with a view to facilitating further exposure and proactive learning.
Learning Outcomes
Knowledge, perspectives and attitudes with respect to documentary:
  • Recognising common documentary tropes and elements
  • Reflecting on conceptual, theoretical and aesthetic aspects
  • Learning ways of analysing and critiquing nonfiction cinema
  • Understanding the integral connections between content and form
  • Learning to recognise the role of image making, sound and editing
  • Understanding ethical dimensions that are critical to documentary practice
  • Responding to varied documentary narratives that have emerged over time
  • Learning basic research skills, developing conceptual rigour and synergy with a team, while working on the final group presentation

description:
Vignettes: Composing Movement for the Spectator [PA-2026] [PA-2026-1]

Faculty Name
Abhinaya Penneswaran [abhinaya.penneswaran@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Movement in performance is essentially bodies in motion meeting the eye of a spectator,
conversing, evoking images and stories. The course aims to enhance this ability to evoke by
learning the tools to craft visual imagery.
The goal is to nurture curiosity for composing and staging movement, and to build skills to
support this. A vast pool of movement vocabulary will be created through elements of body
conditioning, yoga, ballet, contemporary dance and Bharatanatyam, along with shared
experiences of task-based improvisation. This pool will become the primary source of
abstract images and meaningful stories. Using varying elements of movement, sound and
light, visual and aural compositions will be created. Students will be working with short
pieces that can be exhibited/staged and viewed by an audience regularly.

Digitality: Ethnographic Approaches [MS-3090/ SOA-3152] [MS-3090/ SOA-3152-1]

Faculty Name
Chitralekha Dhamija [chitralekha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Ethnography provides an irreplaceable lens to study the lived relationships of digital technologies with human life and cultures, and their constitutive linkages with what it means to be human. While the idea of the digital may be used to refer to binary connections, the computational, electronic, or anything that is internet mediated, ethnographers are interested in the imbrications of these technologies in everyday life and the consequences of the digital for the human condition- in online worlds and in their entanglements with lived realities in physical places. Ethnographic approaches in other words help us explore human interactions with digital devices, the making of human connections in cyberspace, coproduction of notions of the real and the virtual, or the conditions of living and being in a digital culture- that might be called `digitality’. We will examine possibilities of these human engagements in diverse sites and contexts. 

The course will be taught over three sections. 

We first chart some of the conceptual dilemmas in the terrain. How do we approach understandings of `digitality’? In what ways may the digital mediate human life and culture? Are they any different from prior mediations? 

The second section engages with methodological contestations that ethnographers of digital media grapple with. These include existent questions of power, subjectivity, or reflexivity in ethnography in general, but also those that address specific dilemmas in digital ethnography. What does it mean to do ethnography in digital worlds? What may be its analytic advantage to study sociality or politics? Can virtual worlds be studied on their own terms- without ethnographic engagement in the physical worlds that actors in digital places also belong to? What does it mean to conduct multi-sited or multi-timed fieldwork on specific congeries of media practices, forms and agents? How does ethnography help us approach closer towards understandings of digital media in everyday life that is ‘non-media-centric’? Can the study of media beyond media content, as part of the sensory, embodied and affective routines of everyday life, help us arrive at thicker understandings of the possible role of media in social life and change?

Finally, we engage with a range of ethnographic studies of lived histories and vernacular cultures of digital media, exploring local meanings to digital genres of gaming, memes, blogging, or hacking for instance, but also their intersections with existing cultures of class, difference, disability, gender and sexuality etc. 

Learning Outcomes

Students will acquire a theoretical grasp and methodological acquaintance with: 

1. Digitality and its (ethnographic) Dilemmas 

2. Ethnography in/ of Virtual Worlds 

3. Ethnographic Contexts

Overview

This course focuses on the pricing of financial assets. We will talk mostly about the equity market, but later we will also discuss options (puts & calls). The course revolves around different models, methods, and approaches that might help us identify mispriced financial assets which in turn could help us design a reasonably good portfolio. These methods and models have some kind of economic or accounting rationale behind them and some of them are based on groundbreaking papers published in the last century. Despite all that, a student in this course would eventually come to realize that no one model/ method is enough to help us understand the true value of a financial asset. In fact, it is extremely hard to explain why a given object has a particular value and check whether that object is overpriced/ underpriced. Renowned statistician, George Box once said - "all models are wrong, but some are useful". That is what we will try to do in this course - study some models that have been useful in the context of asset pricing. To be specific, we will start with a modern interpretation of Talmudic investing strategy, Markowitz portfolio selection (and maybe some of the later variants if time or your interest permits), factor/ index models, capital asset pricing model (CAPM), and its variants, arbitrage pricing theory, Fama-French three-factor model (maybe briefly discuss the more recent 5-factor model), efficient market hypothesis, equity valuation models, and later we will study options, put-call parity, Black-Scholes' options pricing.

This is a rigorous course, a math- and statistics-based course. If such things tire you, if you are looking for storytelling or a case-studies-based approach, then this course is probably not for you.

Discover the dynamic stories of our changing planet in this elective course, where science meets technology to unravel environmental shifts. Faculty Name
Mitul Baruah [mitul.baruah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course critically examines the processes of “development” and “sustainability,” and the ways in which they interact with each other. The course provides a critical overview of development theories, including classical political economy, modernization theory, dependency theory, postdevelopmentalism, feminist theories of development, sustainable development, and so on. It traces the ideas of development from the 19th century onward, with a particular focus on development thinking in the post-World War II period. At the same time, the course examines certain development projects for a more grounded understanding of how “development” occurs, to whose benefit, and why there is little consensus on what development entails. The course also engages with the multiple ways in which development processes interact with and reshape the environment, thereby affecting the realities of people around the world, and the Global South in particular. To this end, the course specifically focuses on debates and theories around sustainability. It problematizes the idea of sustainability in a world governed by neoliberal development paradigm and faced with both environmental crises and injustices. Upon completing this course, students are expected to learn: 

a. A set of theoretical tools and analytical lenses by which to understand the processes, relationships, and phenomena involved in what we call “development” and “sustainability.”  

b. The distinct implications that different theories of development have for policy, academic work, and social activism and change.

c. The environment-development relations across geographic scales and their planetary and local impacts.

Some of themes will include:

- Theorizing development

- Histories and institutions of development

- The Marxist impasse and the rise of postdependency, and grassroots approaches

- Power, knowledge and development

- Gender, environment and development 

- Sustainable development

- Agriculture and development 

- The gift of Chinese development 

- “Smart city” and India’s developmentalenvironmental challenges

Faculty Name

Overview

The present course uses gender as a lens for looking into the history of medieval and early-modern South Asia. It especially looks at the categories of ‘masculinity’ and ‘ femininity’, how these were constructed and mapped during the period, in relation to one another. In doing so, it considers how evolving ideals of manliness came to inform kingship and domesticity in the Sultanate and the Mughal period. To what extent was the courtly and domestic spaces segregated? What were the ways in which the royal women responded and negotiated with the prescribed norms and participate in politics and court society ? How had art and architectural productions served as sites of gendered patronage, aesthetics, labour and performance ? These are some of the questions that we will address in this course. The course will also explore the non-royal social and political groups, the concubines, dancing girls, women slaves and labourers as well as the gender-liminal figure of the eunuch. The processes of gender marginalisation and defiance of gender normativity will also be taken up, particularly through a study of some of the women saints who challenged societal hierarchies in their pursuit of spirituality. The course will culminate with a discussion on how the medieval notions of gender normativity were reoriented and subverted at the wake of colonialism in the eighteenth century.

Overview

This course examines the making of cities during the Sultanate and early Mughal periods. Students will learn to interpret architecture as both cultural expression and technical accomplishment. The creation of a city reflects a society’s power, wealth, knowledge, and imagination, often embodying its aspirations through the built environment, spatial organization, and ecological relationships. In Islamicate cultures moreover, oral narratives, Sufi lyric traditions, and illustrated manuscripts are crucial in defining cities. They shape the discourses through which cities are perceived and remembered. This course integrates architectural, visual, poetic, and narrative materials that inform the spatial imagination of early modern South Asian cities.

1. Understand the cultural exchange and innovation that defined Sultanate and Mughal Architecture.

Overview

In India, the first moveable printing press was set up in Goa by a Spanish Jesuit missionary in 1556. Prior to Print engages with various dimensions of writing systems and cultures of record-keeping in the Indian subcontinent for approximately two thousand years until the introduction of this technological innovation in the middle of the 16th century. Through a wide array of premodern historical sources—stone and copper plate inscriptions, normative texts, letters, biographies and autobiographies—the course explores questions around articulations of historical consciousness, the relationship between orality and literacy, conversations between texts and visual images, and the materiality of writing. Included among such sources are two unique texts—a 15th century manual for scribes and professional letter writers as well as a delectable cookbook of the early 16th century. Designed as an advanced research course for fourth-year students, this course, through its focus on the production and circulation of various sources, foregrounds aspects of kingship and courtly cultures, networks of merchants and pilgrims, and the establishment of language orders and literary cultures in premodern India.

Reinforcement Learning [CS-5410/ ECO-6410/ MAT-3215] [CS-5410/ ECO-6410/ MAT-3215-1]

Faculty Name
Sandeep Juneja . [sandeep.juneja@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In autonomous vehicles, robots, and many other physical settings, at any state a number of decisions need to be made. Each decision comes with an immediate reward but more importantly leads to another probabilistically selected state. In reinforcement learning, we learn optimal decisions through trial and error where good decisions are reinforced and bad ones are punished. This learning regime, especially when combined with deep learning, is an incredibly powerful tool for artificial and augmented intelligence. In this course we will study the underlying theory and learn to code-up many practical and intricate applications.

Topics covered:

Markov Chains, Markov Decision Processes, Dynamic Programming, Value and Policy Iteration, Temporal Difference Learning, Q-Learning, functional approximations,  Bandit methods, Neural Networks and Deep Q learning, other deep RL methods

courseTitle: Reading Narratives of the Past from South Asia, 1200-1800
description:
Reading Narratives of the Past from South Asia, 1200-1800 [HIS-3223/ ENG-3415] [HIS-3223/ ENG-3415-1]

Faculty Name
Deepashree Dutta [deepashree.dutta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will explore the methodologies of studying the different forms of historical consciousness that informed precolonial South Asia (1200-1800), and will try to discern how different social groups commemorated their pasts. It will move beyond the colonial definition of history as a rational-positivist discipline towards highlighting the literariness of historical writing in the period under study. In the process, the course will introduce the students to a dynamic  multilingual world where linguistic-literary groups and forms existed in constant circulation and interaction with one another, and historical narratives encompassed multiplicity of languages and literary genres. As case in point, the course will take up several literary and language traditions, notably the ‘courtly’ languages of Persian and Sanskrit, along with Marathi, Bengali, Brajbhasha and other vernaculars, which had all flourished in tandem with the political culture of the medieval-early modern period. To what extent did these literary narratives inform the formulation of regional, ethnic and devotional identities? Who were the scribes and the poets? How did the material medium of paper facilitate this literary flourish? These are some of the questions that this course will address. The course will culminate by charting the rise of Urdu literary tradition as reflective of the political flux of the eighteenth century. By the end of the course, students will have an overview of the literary history of history writing in medieval and early modern South Asia.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Students will be expected to prepare and discuss one reading of approximately 30-40 pages for each class. The syllabus as well as the prescribed readings will be provided in advance.

courseTitle: Empire, Utopia and War in the Twentieth Century (1900-1950)
description:
Empire, Utopia and War in the Twentieth Century (1900-1950) [POL-2128] [POL-2128-1]

Faculty Name
Dilip Simeon [dilip.simeon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course will survey major historical developments in the first half of the twentieth century. These include the Great War of 1914-1918; the Bolshevik Revolution and the consolidation of the USSR; the rise of Fascism and Nazism; the crises of the 1930's (such as the Great Crash, the Spanish Civil War and the Sino-Japanese conflict); and the Second World War. The issues I propose to address include the collapse of multinational empires; the reorganisation of the world order; the rise of chauvinist nationalism and economic autarky, and the emergence of ideological regimes in the USSR, Italy, Japan, and Germany. 

I will also introduce students to ideological currents such as militarism, political theology, romantic nationalism, existentialism, historicism and the subversion of law. Thinkers would include Sigmund Freud, Vladimir Lenin, Carl Schmitt, Ernst Fraenkel, Hannah Arendt, Ernst Junger, Martin Heidegger, Leo Strauss and Mahatma Gandhi. The course will be taught in an interlinked manner; and I believe it will be of interest to students from various disciplines. The Indian component will consist of aspects which relate to the world crisis.

Detailed policies, themes, and readings will be provided later
